Graphical abstract This review comprehensively summarizes the research progress on improving the performance of Cu-based material electrocatalysts for ECO2RR via doping regulation. It discusses doping effects of various elements, in-situ characterization, computational methods and future research directions. Electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction is a crucial method for addressing energy issues and achieving carbon neutrality. Doping of Cu catalysts represents an effective approach to regulate electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction. This review article summarizes the research progress on improving the performance of Cu-based material electrocatalysts through doping regulation. The background, fundamental research, evaluation parameters, and methods for catalyst design, along with their influencing factors, are introduced. Emphasis is placed on the impact of doping with different elements (such as noble metals, transition metals, main-group metals, non-metals, etc.) on the performance of Cu-based catalysts, including the mechanisms for enhancing activity, selectivity, and stability. In-situ characterization techniques have revealed the structural evolution and catalytic mechanisms during the doping process. Mechanistic studies, leveraging the ever-advancing computational capabilities and high-throughput methods, have given rise to typical computational descriptors like volcano plots, free-energy diagrams, and machine-learning-based approaches. These descriptors have become key tools for screening high-efficiency catalysts in various application scenarios of the electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR). This article comprehensively summarizes the current research achievements and looks ahead to the future, indicating that strengthening the combination of theory and experiment and exploring industrial applications are the future research directions, aiming to provide a comprehensive reference for the development of highly efficient doped Cu-based electrocatalysts. Keywords Cu-based doped catalysts Electrochemical CO2RR Doping strategies Operando characterization Machine learning descriptors 1 Introduction Since the advent of the Industrial Revolution, fossil resources such as coal, oil, and natural gas have been used as the main raw materials to drive productivity and social development. In contemporary society, fossil resources are notably regarded as the lifeblood of social productivity development. However, the unrestrained exploitation of fossil resources has led to dramatic changes in the global environment and the gradual depletion of resources. The combustion of fossil fuels has caused the continuous excessive emission of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, resulting in severe consequences such as global warming and environmental degradation. The capture and utilization of CO2 can not only promote carbon neutrality and relieve environmental pressure but also use its conversion products as energy sources and raw materials for industrial production, effectively alleviating the dual problems of environmental pollution and energy shortage [1,2]. Based on this, researchers have proposed a feasible plan to promote the global carbon cycle and ultimately achieve global carbon neutrality. That is, using clean energy as the driving force to catalytically convert greenhouse carbon-based molecules such as CO2 to construct an artificial carbon cycle [3-5]. Previous efforts to reduce the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere mainly focused on CO2 capture and storage (CCS). However, due to its advantages in effectiveness and sustainability, the current attention has shifted to CO2 capture and utilization (CCU) [6-8]. Among the numerous proposed CO2 conversion pathways, the electrocatalytic CO2RR technology, which uses electrical energy as the driving force and operates under ambient temperature and pressure, has attracted much attention [9-12]. As a nascent approach in energy transformation systems, electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) has gained recognition as a promising strategy for sustainable chemical synthesis. This methodology facilitates CO2 conversion into high-value chemical commodities and energy carriers, specifically encompassing carbon monoxide, formic acid, methanol, and ethylene, through operational processes conducted under ambient temperature and pressure conditions. Particularly noteworthy is its capability to achieve carbon resource circularity through electrochemical pathways, thereby establishing a closed-loop mechanism for anthropogenic carbon emissions. At the same time, it can also store renewable electrical energy as chemical energy, providing a promising approach to solving energy and environmental problems [13-16]. Among the numerous catalyst materials for electrocatalytic CO2RR, Cu-based materials occupy a special position due to their unique properties [17-20]. Copper has a relatively rich electronic structure and multiple oxidation states, enabling it to catalyze the reduction of carbon dioxide to produce a variety of products, which endows Cu-based catalysts with extensive research value in the field of electrocatalytic CO2RR. Studies have shown that Cu-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance for C2+ products, with a selectivity that can reach 70% [21-25]. Recent advancements in operando characterization methodologies have enabled systematic investigation of intermediate species evolution, valence state transitions, and local coordination environments. These analytical breakthroughs have provided mechanistic insights into the reaction pathways and dynamic structural reorganization of copper-based electrocatalysts during CO2RR, as documented in recent studies [26-29]. Nevertheless, critical challenges persist regarding the catalytic performance metrics of copper-based systems, particularly in terms of product selectivity and long-term operational stability, which currently hinder industrial implementation. To address these limitations, contemporary research has focused on strategic catalyst engineering approaches, including but not limited to nanostructural design, heterointerface construction, lattice strain modulation, and controlled defect introduction [30-34]. Among them, doping regulation is an effective method that can optimize the electronic structure and chemical environment of active sites, precisely regulate product selectivity, enhance stability, inhibit Cu agglomeration and sintering, and resist poisoning [35-38]. Currently, there is a lack of systematic summaries regarding the role of doping control in the electrocatalysis of CO2RR. This study delves into the impact of doping control on the performance of Cu-based materials as catalysts for the electroreduction of carbon dioxide. Through a systematic review and in-depth analysis of relevant research, this paper elucidates the design principles and screening strategies for doped catalysts from both experimental and theoretical perspectives. Furthermore, by employing a variety of advanced characterization techniques, this work comprehensively reveals the intrinsic mechanisms of doping control, aiming to provide theoretical support and practical guidance for the development of efficient carbon dioxide electroreduction catalysts. (Fig. 1 ). This is of significant importance for promoting sustainable energy development and environmental protection and is expected to make a positive contribution towards achieving carbon neutrality goals. 2 Fundamentals and evaluation parameters Understanding the fundamental principles of the electrocatalytic CO2RR is crucial for the design of highly efficient electrocatalysts. The pathways from gaseous carbon dioxide to different desired products typically involve various chemical and physical processes. As indicated by theoretical simulations and experimental studies, electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction mainly encompasses the activation of carbon dioxide, surface reactions, and product desorption processes [39-44]. This section will introduce the basic reaction principles, evaluation metrics, and challenges of electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction. 2.1 Thermodynamics of CO2RR CO2 is a thermally stable compound characterized by a fully oxidized linear geometric configuration. The bond dissociation energy of the C=O bond in CO2 is roughly 750 kJ mol−1, suggesting that significant activation energy and energy input are necessary for the direct cleavage of this bond. Fig. 2 a illustrates the molecular-level reaction pathway, systematically detailing the advancements and challenges associated with the electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide [45]. The proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) mechanism of the catalyst is of paramount importance, as protons and electrons may engage either independently or collaboratively in each step of the process [46-48]. It is essential to highlight the roles of pH and potential, which are critical in influencing both the reactivity and selectivity of the reduction products. For instance, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) can take place at both elevated and reduced potentials, acting as a competing reaction with ECO2RR and posing challenges for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. The presence of multiple intermediates significantly impacts the reaction pathways and the resulting products. The selectivity of CO2RR is dictated by the binding affinities of *COOH, *OCHO, *CO, and *H on the catalyst surface [49,50]. The primary transformation processes of carbon dioxide encompass its conversion into C1, C2, and C3 products. Formic acid is a significant liquid product formed from the CO2RR via a two-electron transfer reaction. Initial mechanistic investigations revealed that the pathway for its synthesis does not rely on hydrocarbon intermediates, indicating that *CO is not an essential precursor for the generation of formic acid. Additional theoretical analyses and experimental validations suggest the existence of three distinct pathways for formic acid production. The first pathway involves the adsorption of a carbon atom from CO2 onto the catalyst surface, followed by the protonation of the oxygen atom in CO2, leading to the formation of the *COOH intermediate. The second pathway entails the binding of both oxygen atoms from CO2 to the catalyst, with subsequent protonation of the carbon atom to yield the HCOO* intermediate, which is then converted to HCOOH through a PCET step. The third pathway builds on the second, wherein protons and electrons associated with HCOO* are progressively transferred to create the *OCHO intermediate. In contrast, the production of CO predominantly relies on the *CO species, which serves as a critical rate-limiting factor in hydrocarbon formation. For instance, a collaborative study by the Jaramillo group, combining experimental and theoretical approaches, established the formation mechanisms of HCOOH and CO on a polycrystalline Sn surface. Their findings indicated that *OCHO acts as the intermediate for HCOOH, while *COOH serves as the intermediate for CO [52]. Additionally, the synthesis of CH3OH, HCOH, and CH4 results from the *CO species undergoing the PCET process, with variations arising from the differing quantities of protons and electrons involved. In the domain of ECO2RR, the formation of carbon-carbon (C–C) bonds is a highly intriguing phenomenon, predominantly occurring on Cu-based electrocatalysts, which opens up avenues for generating C2 products. Due to the considerable economic value and energy density associated with C2 products, extensive theoretical and experimental investigations have been dedicated to exploring their pathways for carbon dioxide conversion. Initial research indicated that *CO acts as a crucial intermediate in the synthesis of hydrocarbons and oxygenated compounds, with C2H4, C2H5OH, and CH3COOH serving as representative C2 products. For instance, in the case of ethylene production, the Koper group identified two distinct pathways on the single-crystal copper surface. Typically, the high-overpotential pathway observed at elevated pH levels involves the shared *CHO intermediate on copper alongside the methane pathway (111). Conversely, Cu(100) demonstrates a low-overpotential pathway at lower pH, where the CO dimer intermediate plays a pivotal role and shares the same intermediate with the C2H6 formation mechanism. Recent computational and experimental findings have provided substantial evidence that low overpotentials and alkaline electrolytes facilitate CO dimerization, aligning with earlier research conclusions [53]. While a complete explanation of these influencing factors remains elusive, the establishment of a continuous electrolyte system characterized by a high local pH appears to be a promising strategy for enhancing hydrocarbon production. Furthermore, during the ECO2RR process, reactions involving ethanol, acetic acid, ketene, and acetaldehyde on the copper surface have also been documented. It is widely accepted that these products are synthesized through the common intermediate OCCOH (a hydrogenated CO dimer intermediate) on the Cu surface, with the selectivity relationships being contingent upon the number of PCET involved. In this context, Calle-Vallejo and Koper initially suggested that the *CH–CO intermediate might be the critical intermediate for ethanol production [54]. Recently, Kang et al. validated the thermodynamic viability of converting the *CH–CO intermediate into ethanol and acetic acid on Cu(111), proposing that the addition of water to yield acetic acid products is kinetically plausible. Notably, investigations into the coverage of the *CO intermediate for ethanol production on Cu(100) and Cu(111) have shown that an increase in surface *CO coverage enhances the formation of oxidation products [55]. The reaction pathways for C2 products are illustrated in Fig. 2a. It is important to emphasize that multiple competing pathways operate concurrently across a broad potential spectrum and can be significantly influenced by the overpotential [45]. The synthesis of multicarbon compounds (C3 species) has been identified as a catalytic phenomenon predominantly mediated by copper-derived nanostructured materials in the ECO2RR. Current technological limitations manifest as suboptimal electron transfer efficiencies for propanol synthesis (<25%), with the fundamental mechanisms governing C3 product formation remaining insufficiently elucidated. While significant knowledge gaps persist, current mechanistic models propose a viable pathway involving stabilization of C2 intermediates followed by sequential C1 monomer incorporation. Theoretical simulations suggest two distinct coupling configurations (CO–CH2CHO and CO–OCCO) satisfy thermodynamic prerequisites for C3 generation, with OCCOCO* emerging as the most plausible triatomic carbon intermediate [56]. Recent advancements in catalyst engineering have yielded three principal optimization approaches: spatial confinement effects, asymmetric active centers, and vacancy-mediated coordination systems. Experimental validation of these strategies has been predominantly conducted on copper-based systems. Notably, the implementation of nanoscale copper cavities has demonstrated enhanced intermediate stabilization capabilities, achieving propanol production efficiencies approaching 21% (FE). Complementary studies reveal that architecturally segmented copper catalysts containing dual-function sites facilitate C1-C2 coupling processes, attaining comparable FE values of ∼20% [57-59]. Contrary to theoretical predictions, in-situ spectroscopic analyses have failed to detect transient C3-radical species or reactive intermediates during the proposed CO insertion steps. This empirical-evidence paradox highlights critical challenges in reaction pathway validation. From an application perspective, the commercial viability of ECO2RR-derived C3 compounds remains constrained by two interdependent factors: unsatisfactory product selectivity and insufficient catalytic turnover frequencies, both requiring fundamental breakthroughs in catalyst design and mechanistic understanding. It is worth noting that in ECO2RR, the HER seems to be an inevitable concomitant process. Proton participation in electrocatalytic systems presents a dualistic role: while serving as a critical prerequisite for hydrocarbon and oxygenated product formation, excessive proton availability promotes parasitic H2 evolution that compromises carbon-based product selectivity[60]. This fundamental dichotomy necessitates a multifaceted optimization strategy encompassing coordinated development of catalyst architectures, electrolyte formulations, and reactor configurations to achieve optimal proton management. To address this challenge, a rational design of the catalytic system is essential, including all aspects such as electrocatalysts, electrolytes, and electrolyzers [61-63]. 2.2 Kinetics of CO2RR The kinetic behavior at the electrode interface critically governs both the selectivity and formation kinetics of electrochemical products. This potential-dependent behavior is classically characterized through current-density versus overpotential profiles. In the low-overpotential regime (η < 50 mV), cathodic current density exhibits a progressive increase with applied overpotential, indicative of reaction control through interfacial charge-transfer kinetics. Conversely, under elevated overpotentials (η > 200 mV), the current density approaches a transport-limited plateau (i l,n), demonstrating independence from further potential variations. Such potential-dependent transitions provide mechanistic insights into the rate-determining processes, enabling precise correlation between electrochemical responses and underlying physical phenomena. Systematic investigations over recent decades have elucidated fundamental aspects governing CO2 reduction kinetics, including charge-transfer mechanisms, mass transport constraints, and catalyst-electrolyte interactions, which will be methodically analyzed in subsequent sections. The CO2RR proceeds through multiple parallel pathways initiated by PCET following CO2 activation. These pathways involve sequential surface reactions including C–O bond cleavage, C–C coupling, and C–H bond formation, which collectively determine the final product distribution. The OCHO intermediate facilitates formic acid formation through oxygen atom bonding with the catalyst surface while retaining the original C=O bond of CO2. In contrast, COOH intermediates generated via C=O bond cleavage lead to adsorbed CO species, which may either desorb as gaseous CO or participate in C–C coupling through dimerization and subsequent PCET steps to form C2 products. Hydrogenation of CO produces COH intermediates that serve as precursors for CH4 and CH3OH, while C2H4 can further react with CO to generate C3 species. Notably, desorbed CO may undergo additional reduction via the CO reduction reaction (CORR) to form higher hydrocarbons, though experimental validation of these transient intermediates remains challenging due to their short lifetimes. The adsorption/desorption equilibrium of intermediates at each reaction stage significantly influences overall catalytic performance, yet the precise identification of rate-limiting steps remains unresolved. Additionally, CO2RR requires specific electron counts for product formation: 2 electrons for CO, 6 for CH3OH, 8 for CH4, and 12 for C2H4. It can be seen that the electron transfer process not only affects the reduction rate of carbon dioxide but also influences the product selectivity. In the field of electrochemistry, the charge transfer resistance (R ct) can be used to evaluate the ability of electrons to transfer from the catalyst surface to reactants and intermediates. The R ct, which is quantified through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), exhibits an inverse correlation with interfacial electron transfer kinetics. Specifically, lower R ct values indicate enhanced charge mobility. Meanwhile, mass transport limitations play a crucial role in governing the dynamics of CO2 electroreduction, as the reaction cascade necessitates the coordinated movement of multiple species. This process encompasses three sequential stages: (1) CO2 dissolution into the electrolyte phase, (2) dissolved CO2 diffusion through the electrolyte bulk to the electrode-electrolyte interface, and (3) surface migration of activated CO2 species to catalytically active sites. Each transport stage imposes distinct kinetic barriers that collectively determine the overall reaction rate and product distribution profiles. In the charge transfer resistance CO2RR, processes such as the migration of intermediates at the interface of the heterogeneous electrocatalyst and the diffusion of products from the reaction interface to the electrolyte also have an important impact on the reaction. In the study of the kinetics of CO2RR, Fig. 2b and c play a crucial role. They conduct in-depth analyses of the profound impact of intermediate binding energies on the reaction process from different dimensions, providing key clues for understanding and optimizing this reaction [51]. Fig. 2b focuses on the key descriptor relationships in the process of electroreduction of CO2 to generate H2, CO, and HCOOH. Through an innovative three-dimensional spatial plotting method, with coupled binding energy ellipsoids (representing the top 5 confidence intervals calculated relative to Au) and Au error ellipsoids (reflecting the errors of the slab and gas phase), it intuitively presents the complex correlations among the binding energies of H*, COOH, and CO (H2 in red, formic acid in yellow, CO in blue, and CO* in cyan). This presentation deeply reveals how these binding energies affect the reaction process at the atomic level, thereby precisely regulating the generation of H2, CO, and HCOOH. For example, the differences in the binding energies of these intermediates on different metal surfaces directly determine the choice of reaction pathways and the reaction rates of CO2 on those surfaces. When a metal has a relatively strong binding energy for COOH, it may prompt CO2 to be more inclined to generate CO or HCOOH. Meanwhile, the magnitude of the H* binding energy plays a critical role in the competition between the HER and the CO2RR. A moderate H* binding energy helps to promote CO2RR and avoid HER from dominating. Fig. 2c, on the other hand, mainly demonstrates the unique role of intermediate binding energies (ΔE CO* and ΔE H*) in distinguishing CO* (hydrocarbon or alcohol) products, especially highlighting the special position of the Cu metal catalyst. As the only metal catalyst capable of producing CO products, Cu is clearly distinguished from other metals by virtue of its unique binding energy characteristic of binding CO without hydrogen underpotential deposition (Hupd). The ellipsoids in the Fig. 2c clearly represent the coupled first confidence intervals of the binding energies relative to Au, and the black lines clearly show the thermodynamic situations of adsorbed or non-adsorbed hydrogen (ΔG H* = 0, corresponding to 1/2H2 ↔ H*) and CO (ΔG CO* = 0, corresponding to CO ↔ CO*). From a kinetic perspective, the binding ability of Cu to CO and the characteristic that Hupd is absent endow the adsorption and subsequent conversion steps of CO on the Cu surface with specific energy and rate characteristics. This property makes the reaction intermediates on Cu more likely to undergo reactions such as C–C coupling or hydrogenation, thus generating hydrocarbon products like methane and ethylene or alcohol products like ethanol. In contrast, other metals, due to the lack of such binding energy characteristics of Cu, have difficulty effectively converting CO into CO products. This significant difference fully reflects the key regulatory role of binding energies in reaction pathways and kinetics, which directly determines the distribution of the final products of CO2RR as well as the reaction rate and direction. Based on Fig. 2b and c, it can be concluded that the properties of metal surfaces (especially the binding energies for different intermediates) are the core elements that determine the product distribution and reaction rate of CO2RR. In the research field of improving the performance of Cu-based electrocatalysts for carbon dioxide reduction through doping regulation, a profound understanding of these relationships is of great significance. It provides a theoretical basis for designing high-performance catalysts. By rationally doping with other elements to regulate the electronic structure of Cu-based materials, it is expected to change their binding energies for intermediates such as H*, COOH*, CO, and CH3O. Such changes can effectively influence the active sites and reaction pathways of the reaction, guiding CO2RR to proceed in the expected direction, ultimately improving the selectivity and generation rate of the target products and promoting the development and application of CO2RR technology. In the elaboration of the above CO2RR kinetics, an in-depth analysis of the intermediate binding energy was first conducted to understand its crucial regulatory role in the reaction pathways and product distributions. However, the complexity of CO2RR kinetics goes far beyond this. Previous relevant reports pointed out that when the ECO2RR was carried out on a polycrystalline silver (Ag) electrode under low overpotential conditions, the Tafel slope was 132 mV dec−1 [64]. This phenomenon indicates that the rate-determining step of this reaction is the transfer of the initial electron to carbon dioxide to form the surface-adsorbed *COOH intermediate. This means that due to the low consumption rate of carbon dioxide in this process, its transport process will not limit the supply of carbon dioxide. However, when carbon dioxide reduction is carried out on the surface of nanoporous silver, the intrinsic performance of CO2RR is enhanced, and at this time, the Tafel slope drops to 58 mV dec−1 [65]. This change shows that the rate-limiting step may be related to the diffusion of carbon dioxide and the rates at which products enter and exit the nanopores of the catalyst. In addition to the factors mentioned above, conditions such as electrolytes, temperature, and pressure can also have an impact on the kinetic process of CO2RR, which is an extremely complex process. Therefore, in-depth exploration of the CO2RR process is a formidable yet significant task, and there is still a long way to go. 2.3 Evaluation metrics for electrochemical CO2 reduction With the development of the CO2RR, the relevant evaluation indicators have also been gradually refined. To assess the performance of electro-catalysts and catalytic systems for carbon dioxide reduction, several basic parameters need to be considered, mainly including the onset potential, overpotential (η), FE, EE, Tafel slope, partial current density (J), turnover frequency (TOF), and stability. It should be noted that when evaluating the overall performance of a catalyst, all of these indicators should be considered comprehensively. Under ideal conditions, a high-performance catalyst should have high Faraday efficiency, current density, energy efficiency, and stability when operating at a low overpotential. (1) Onset potential: Representing the threshold electrode potential required to initiate a specific electrochemical reaction. Catalysts exhibiting more positive onset potentials demonstrate enhanced intrinsic activity, as this parameter inversely correlates with the thermodynamic overpotential needed to drive electrocatalytic reduction processes. Lower activation barriers at positive onset potentials enable kinetically favorable reaction pathways with reduced energy input requirements. (2) Overpotential (η): Representing the potential difference between applied and equilibrium potentials (η = E − E eq), this parameter quantifies the excess energy required to drive the electrocatalytic reduction process. Its magnitude directly correlates with the kinetic barrier of the reaction. (3) Faraday efficiency (FE): Defined as the ratio of charge selectively utilized for target product formation to total charge consumption, FE is calculated through the relationship FE = (αnF)/Q. Here, α denotes the electron transfer count per product molecule (e.g., α=2 for CO2-to-CO conversion), n represents the molar quantity of generated product, F is the Faraday constant (96,485 C mol−1), and Q signifies total charge transfer. This metric serves as a direct indicator of catalytic selectivity. (4) Energy efficiency (EE): Characterizing the total energy utilization effectiveness, EE is expressed as EE = E 0 * FE / (E 0+η), where E0 corresponds to the thermodynamic equilibrium potential. This parameter integrates both thermodynamic and kinetic considerations. (5) Tafel slope: Derived from the logarithmic correlation between overpotential and current density, this kinetic parameter inversely relates to catalytic performance-lower slope values indicate superior electrocatalytic activity. (6) Partial current density (J): This metric quantifies the current contribution specifically attributable to target product formation, dependent on parameters including intrinsic catalytic activity, active site density, mass transport efficiency, and system impedance. Valid comparisons require strict standardization of experimental conditions across catalyst systems. (7) Turnover frequency (TOF): Expressing the number of catalytic cycles per active site per unit time, TOF provides fundamental insights into site-specific activity. Elevated TOF values signify enhanced reactivity of catalytic centers, directly reflecting their capacity to accelerate reaction kinetics. (8) Stability: Stability is an indicator for evaluating the service life of a catalyst under actual working conditions and can be used to determine whether the catalyst has the potential for practical applications. A common testing method is to carry out long-term potentiostatic electrolysis on the catalyst at the potential of the FE peak and observe whether the current density and the FE of the product change significantly. The ideal catalyst should be designed to maintain J and FE and not increase the overpotential η during long-term continuous operation. When studying the performance of Cu-based materials in the electroreduction of carbon dioxide, key evaluation indicators such as onset potential, η, FE, EE, and stability reveal their performance during the reaction process from multiple aspects, enabling an in-depth understanding of the behavioral characteristics of Cu-based materials in the electroreduction of carbon dioxide. In order to continuously improve the catalytic performance of Cu-based materials to achieve more efficient, more selective, and long-term stable electro-reduction and conversion of carbon dioxide, a series of control strategies have been widely explored and studied. As shown in Fig. 3 , this has injected vitality into the development of this field [66,67]. Interface regulation is an important approach. On the one hand, surface modification can cover a layer of specific substances on the surface of Cu-based materials through physical or chemical methods. For example, depositing an ultrathin layer of metal oxide on its surface can change the electronic structure and chemical environment of the surface and enhance the adsorption and activation ability of carbon dioxide. On the other hand, interface engineering is committed to optimizing the interfacial interaction between Cu-based materials and substrates or other functional materials and constructing a heterogeneous interface with a strong coupling effect. For example, loading copper nanoparticles on a specific carbon-based material can improve catalytic activity and stability through charge transfer between interfaces [65-67]. The precise control of structure and morphology also plays a crucial role. In terms of structure control, by controlling the synthesis conditions to prepare Cu-based materials with different crystal structures, such as changing from the common face-centered cubic structure to the tetragonal phase structure, the atomic arrangement can be adjusted, and the electron conduction path and the distribution of catalytic active sites can be changed [71]. For morphology control, the preparation of Cu-based materials with a specific shape is very effective. For instance, one-dimensional or two-dimensional structures such as nanowires and nanosheets can be fabricated. Compared with traditional bulk materials, the nanowire structure has a large aspect ratio, which is beneficial to electron transmission, and the nanosheet structure has a large specific surface area and can provide more catalytic active sites, thereby improving reaction efficiency and selectivity [72-74]. The tandem catalysis strategy shows unique advantages. The surface-interface tandem catalytic system rationally combines materials with different catalytic functions on the surface-interface. For example, closely connecting materials that can efficiently adsorb carbon dioxide with the Cu-based active sites that are good at catalyzing carbon dioxide conversion, a relay-type catalytic reaction path is constructed. Carbon dioxide molecules are first enriched and preliminarily activated on the adsorbent material and then quickly transferred to the Cu-based active sites for in-depth reduction reaction, which greatly improves the overall efficiency and selectivity of the reaction and breaks through the limitation of the catalytic performance of a single material [75-78]. Among numerous regulation methods, doping, as a widely studied and effective strategy, demonstrates unique advantages. Doping can precisely adjust the electronic structure, lattice parameters, and surface chemical properties of Cu-based materials by introducing foreign atoms, thereby exerting a profound impact on their catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. Compared with other methods, doping has the characteristics of relatively simple operation and being easy to achieve atomic-level precise regulation. It can significantly optimize the performance of materials without significantly changing their overall structures, thus providing new opportunities and directions for the further development of Cu-based materials in the field of carbon dioxide electroreduction. Subsequently, the important role of doping methods and their influencing factors in improving the carbon dioxide electroreduction performance of Cu-based materials will be focused on. All in all, these diverse regulation strategies have provided abundant approaches and possibilities for the development of Cu-based materials in the field of carbon dioxide electroreduction. Subsequently, doping, as a key strategy, will be focused on. This paper will systematically sort out and summarize the recent research progress in the field of metal or non-metal doping, and deeply explore the important role of its methods and influencing factors in improving the carbon dioxide electroreduction performance of Cu-based materials, to provide comprehensive and in-depth theoretical and practical guidance for the further development of this field. 3 Design strategies for Cu-based doped catalysts In the research field of doping in Cu-based catalysts, multiple factors are intertwined, jointly determining the doping effect and the degree of improvement in catalyst performance. The technical roadmap for doping regulation to improve the performance of Cu-based electrocatalysts for carbon dioxide reduction is shown in Fig. 4 . The size of ions affects the occupation of doping atoms in the copper lattice, thereby changing the lattice strain and electron cloud distribution; the difference in valence regulates the electronic properties of active sites through charge transfer, playing a crucial role in the adsorption and activation of reactants; and the reactivity is directly related to the rate and selectivity of the catalytic process [79-81]. Meanwhile, from the perspective of material design, one-dimensional, two-dimensional, and three-dimensional material structures each have their unique characteristics in terms of electron conduction, mass diffusion, and exposure of active sites. Different compositional forms such as single metals, oxides, compounds, bimetals, and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) also bring diverse performance manifestations to the catalysts [82,83]. In addition, the choice of preparation method cannot be ignored. Physical mixing, chemical methods, electrochemical methods, and heat treatment methods can introduce doping atoms into the Cu-based system in different ways, achieving fine regulation of the microscopic structure and macroscopic performance of the catalysts [84-86]. This part will deeply explore how these key factors, design concepts, and preparation methods work synergistically to promote the development of doping technology for Cu-based catalysts, enhance their catalytic efficiency in various chemical reactions, provide comprehensive and systematic theoretical and practical guidance for in-depth research on doping of Cu-based materials, and drive their further development and application in the catalytic field. 3.1 Core factors influencing the doping effect Doping constitutes a foundational materials engineering approach that enables the controlled integration of foreign atoms or ions into host matrices. This technique has been historically employed to modulate the physicochemical properties of solid-state systems. Through deliberate manipulation of Fermi levels, doping achieves precise regulation of charge carrier transport mechanisms involving both electrons and holes in semiconductor architectures, forming a cornerstone principle for modern optoelectronic device functionality. Recent developments in nanoscale synthesis methodologies have significantly advanced doping precision, now permitting atomic-scale control across diverse material systems. These encompass crystalline dielectric materials, quantum-confined semiconductor structures, and hybrid organic-inorganic frameworks. The resulting engineered materials demonstrate customized electronic configurations and emergent functional characteristics that remain unattainable in their undoped counterparts. The effectiveness of doping processes primarily hinges on the chemical compatibility between dopant species and host lattice cations. Key governing parameters include ionic radius matching, electronegativity alignment, and valence state equivalence. Contemporary doping strategies systematically exploit these fundamental principles to design defect states that strategically modulate critical performance factors in electrochemical systems. These factors include charge separation efficiency, surface reaction kinetics, and carrier transport capabilities. 3.1.1 Size of ions Ionic dimensions are defined by the equilibrium interionic distances within crystalline lattices. The structural stability of ionic compounds arises from the geometric constraints imposed by the cation-to-anion ionic radius ratio, as described by the crystal coordination rule proposed by Goldschmidt. Maximum structural stability occurs when the central cation attains its characteristic coordination number through optimal spatial arrangement of surrounding anions. Consequently, ionic size matching constitutes a critical determinant in dopant substitution processes, where foreign cations must satisfy both charge balance and radius compatibility requirements to maintain lattice integrity during host cation replacement [87]. Usually, when ions of similar sizes in a crystalline compound substitute for each other, there will be no significant change in the crystal structure, and a complete solid solution can be formed, which can be conveniently doped with Cu-based materials. For example, according to the research by Wan et al., in the copper-zinc oxide system, the ionic radius of Zn2+ is similar to that of Cu2+. When Zn2+ partially replaces Cu2+, the crystal structure of the formed copper-zinc oxide solid solution remains basically unchanged, and this material exhibits good catalytic performance in the electrochemical reduction reaction of carbon dioxide, with indicators such as current density and product selectivity being better than those of the undoped Cu-based materials [88,89]. However, if there is a large difference in size between the dopant and the host cation, the doping ions may not be able to enter the host lattice smoothly due to steric hindrance and other reasons. Research reveals that dopants exhibit preferential stabilization at high-coordination cation sites (CN≥6), including octahedral (CN=6) and cubic (CN=8) coordination geometries. In perovskite-structured copper oxide composites, for instance, incorporation of larger ionic radii dopants favors occupation of high-CN positions, thereby inducing targeted structural modifications that profoundly influence oxygen vacancy formation energies and charge transport characteristics. This site-selective doping mechanism enables precise tuning of metal-oxygen bond lengths and Bader charge distributions, ultimately dictating catalytic activity through ligand field stabilization effects and electron density redistribution patterns [90]. 3.1.2 Valence Cation doping processes exhibit distinct characteristics depending on the valence matching between dopant and host ions. Isovalent substitution, where dopant ions share equivalent valence states with host cations, generally induces minimal lattice distortion and is therefore thermodynamically favored. However, heterovalent doping, as exemplified by Al3+ incorporation into divalent copper sites in Cu-based catalysts [91], requires compensatory mechanisms to preserve charge neutrality. These stabilization processes typically generate localized lattice defects such as interstitial ions or cation vacancies. The charge compensation requirement imposes inherent constraints on maximum dopant concentrations. For instance, in nickel-doped copper oxide systems employed for CO2 electroreduction, Ni2+ substitution at Cu2+ sites introduce vacancy defects that maintain electrostatic equilibrium. Such defect-mediated stabilization mechanisms often result in increased lattice strain energy, ultimately limiting the dopant solubility threshold. This phenomenon underscores the critical balance between charge compensation efficacy and structural stability in engineered catalyst systems [92,93]. For example, in some cases, interstitial ions will be generated, that is, some additional ions will enter the lattice interstitial positions; at the same time, vacancy defects will also appear. That is, in the lattice positions where Cu2+ was originally located, after Ni2+ replacement, the local vacancy may occur in the arrangement of surrounding atoms [94]. Due to these charge-balance and related local lattice distortion problems, the upper limit of the Ni2+ doping concentration will be limited. As the Ni2+ doping concentration increases, the degree of lattice distortion increases, which will lead to a decrease in the stability of the crystal structure of the material, thus affecting its performance in the electrochemical CO2RR. Therefore, its doping concentration cannot be increased indefinitely. To break through this limitation, it is necessary to precisely control experimental variables such as temperature, pH value, and the molar ratio of raw materials in the synthesis process to optimize the doping effect, so as to better improve the performance of the material in the electrochemical CO2RR. 3.1.3 Reaction characteristics For a dopant to penetrate the host lattice and form a stable substitute, it must possess reactivity similar to that of the host cation. If the difference in chemical reactivity is too great, the unbalanced ions in the lattice will be repelled. A similar mechanism also prevents the doping atoms from effectively binding to the host. For example, Li et al. found during their research on the doping of copper-based sulfides that when the reactivity of the dopant differed significantly from that of Cu+ even if the conditions such as ion size and valence were relatively suitable, the activity of the doped material in the electrochemical CO2RR did not improve significantly and even deteriorated. This was mainly due to the inability of the doping atoms to form effective chemical bonds with the host lattice, thus affecting the charge transfer and the adsorption and activation processes of reaction intermediates [95]. 3.1.4 Roughness and porosity of the substrate In the research field of doping regulation for improving the performance of Cu-based electro-catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction, the roughness and porosity of the substrate, as the key factors determining the doping effect, play a vital role. From the perspective of the roughness of the substrate, the undulations and irregularities at the microscopic level play a fundamental role. At the atomic scale, the special sites such as abundant steps and edges on the rough surface have a relatively low coordination number and a certain number of unsaturated bonds, which create suitable adsorption sites for the doping atoms. When common doping methods such as physical vapor deposition and chemical solution methods are used, the doping atoms can attach to the substrate more effectively and form a stable bond with the substrate atoms, thereby significantly increasing the success rate of doping and promoting the uniform distribution of doping. Moreover, the atomic diffusion behavior during the doping process is significantly affected by the roughness. The atomic diffusion paths under thermal diffusion or with the assistance of external forces become circuitous and complex due to the maze-like microscopic structure of the rough surface. The atoms no longer move along a simple straight-line trajectory, but meander along the undulations of the surface. On the one hand, this situation allows the doping atoms to have more sufficient time to interact with the substrate atoms, which is beneficial for forming an ideal doping structure. On the other hand, if the process parameters such as temperature and time can be precisely controlled, the doping atoms can be skillfully guided to gather in specific regions, which is a practical and efficient strategy for preparing materials with gradient doping characteristics. In addition, the surface irregularities caused by roughness will create a unique stress-strain distribution state between the substrate and the doping layer. Once the doping atoms are incorporated into the substrate lattice, the lattice distortion caused by the difference in atomic radius presents a complex situation on the rough substrate. The atoms are closely packed at the peak parts and bear a large compressive stress, while the concave regions show tensile stress or relatively small compressive stress. Such an unbalanced stress-strain field has a far-reaching impact on the electrical and mechanical properties of the materials [96,97]. When used reasonably, it can activate additional carriers, generate dislocations to accommodate more doping atoms, and enhance the stability of the materials. If not properly controlled, it may lead to negative effects such as cracks and inter-layer peeling. Focusing on the porosity of the substrate, its abundant pore structures (with a size range covering from the nanometer to micrometer scale) provide numerous conveniences for the doping process. In the initial stage, gaseous or liquid doping sources can smoothly penetrate into the interior by virtue of the permeation characteristics of the pores, enabling the doping atoms to be efficiently adsorbed and deposited on the pore walls and in the internal space. These pores are just like natural and efficient transmission channels. Compared with dense substrates, they greatly reduce the transmission resistance of the doping atoms and make their diffusion process smoother. This can not only significantly improve the doping efficiency and shorten the doping time but also open up a mild and efficient doping path for substrate materials or doping processes that are sensitive to temperature and pressure. The porosity also leads to a substantial increase in the specific surface area of the substrate, exposing a large number of active sites. In doping applications related to catalysis, these sites work in synergy with the doping atoms and demonstrate an excellent performance improvement effect. Taking the catalysis of chemical reactions by metal dopants loaded on the substrate as an example, metal atoms can be evenly dispersed on the pore surfaces and closely cooperate with active oxygen, hydroxyl and other groups on the edges of the pores to jointly build efficient catalytic active centers, accurately adsorbing, activating and transforming reactant molecules, and playing a key role in many fields such as energy conversion and environmental purification. From a macroscopic perspective, porosity has a comprehensive and in-depth optimization effect on the overall performance of the doped materials. In terms of mechanical properties, an appropriate amount of pores, like buffer structures, can effectively disperse the stress when external forces are applied, absorb part of the energy, prevent the fracture risk caused by stress concentration, and endow the materials with better toughness. In the aspect of thermal properties, the air or filling medium in the pores has a low thermal conductivity, which can effectively reduce the overall thermal conduction efficiency of the materials and meet the actual needs of doping modification of high-temperature thermal insulation materials. In the field of electrical properties, if the pore structure and doping layout are rationally planned, the pores can act as electron scattering centers to flexibly regulate the electron mobility, meeting the customized requirements of various electronic devices for the electrical properties of materials [98]. All in all, precisely controlling the roughness and porosity of the substrate and deeply understanding their inherent action mechanisms are of inestimable value for optimizing the doping regulation strategies and preparing high-performance Cu-based electro-catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction. They are the core points for promoting the continuous development of this research field. 3.2 Properties and challenges of Cu-based materials In the field of catalytic science, Cu-based catalysts exhibit unique catalytic properties by virtue of numerous characteristics such as their distinctive and complex crystal structures, surface architectures, and electronic structures. They are currently the only known metal catalysts capable of producing multi-carbon products in the electrocatalytic process of carbon dioxide reduction. Compared with other metal catalysts, they possess significant advantages in the electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide, providing valuable research directions and application potential for the efficient conversion and utilization of carbon dioxide. However, there are still limitations in their catalytic performance in practical applications. From the perspective of valence states, the adjustable range of the valence state of a single Cu-based catalyst during the reaction process is limited, making it difficult to meet the requirements for multiple redox states in complex reactions. For example, in some redox reactions, the insufficient number of copper active sites at specific valence states leads to limited reaction efficiency. Moreover, the hydrogen evolution problem is also quite prominent. In some electrocatalytic processes (such as the electroreduction of carbon dioxide), the HER on the surface of Cu-based catalysts is highly competitive. This not only reduces the selectivity of the target products but also causes energy waste. In addition, there are also deficiencies in terms of stability. Under long-term reaction conditions, Cu-based catalysts may become deactivated due to structural changes, poisoning of active sites, and other reasons. Extensive research demonstrates that rational engineering of copper-based electrocatalysts substantially improves both catalytic activity and C2+ product selectivity in ECO2RR. By strategically modifying catalyst composition, microstructure, and surface characteristics, researchers can precisely tune electronic structures to generate abundant active sites while optimizing intermediate adsorption energetics. As depicted in Fig. 5 , such doping strategies enable directional steering of reaction pathways through controlled binding strength of key intermediates within the optimal Sabatier principle window. Effective catalyst design necessitates balancing intermediate adsorption strength to avoid either excessive bonding that hinders further transformations or insufficient stabilization that prevents subsequent reactions. This balance is achieved through coordinated adjustments in material composition, nanostructured morphology, crystalline phase orientation, defect density, interfacial properties, and lattice strain distribution. For instance, nickel-modified copper oxides enhance *CO adsorption via d-band center modulation, facilitating efficient C–C coupling while maintaining appropriate intermediate mobility. These integrated engineering approaches simultaneously accelerate reaction kinetics and enhance multi-carbon product selectivity by precisely controlling the thermodynamic landscape of surface processes. Systematic optimization of these parameters has been shown to significantly improve Faradaic efficiency and operational stability in advanced electrocatalytic systems. Nanoscale doping strategies extend beyond conventional single-phase systems, enabled by advances in nanostructure engineering. Contemporary synthesis techniques allow precise spatial confinement of dopant species within defined nanocrystalline regions through dimensional control of nanostructured architectures. These include nanoparticles with tailored facet exposures, anisotropic nanorods, layered nanosheets, and complex hierarchical assemblies (Fig. 5) [96,99,100]. Such structural precision facilitates site-selective multi-dopant incorporation via controlled epitaxial growth processes, as demonstrated in segmented nanorod systems and flower-like nanoarchitectures [101,102]. Dopant integration strategies exhibit remarkable versatility across material platforms. Metal centers can be atomically dispersed on two-dimensional supports or coordinated within MOF matrices. Current research focuses on diverse copper-based host systems encompassing metallic copper matrices, copper oxide derivatives, copper chalcogenide compounds, bimetallic alloys, and MOF-immobilized copper centers. This material diversity enables systematic optimization of dopant-host interactions while maintaining structural integrity under operational conditions. 3.3 Doping methods The broad applicability of doping techniques in catalytic systems has driven the advancement of diverse synthesis methodologies aimed at achieving homogeneous heteroatom incorporation. Mature doping strategies encompass techniques such as chemical reduction, electrochemical deposition, physical blending, and thermal annealing processes, as systematically categorized in Fig. 6 . Effective dopant integration typically requires precise modulation of synthesis parameters or selection of dopant species exhibiting ionic radii and electronic configurations compatible with the host matrix. When substantial disparities exist in physicochemical properties, particularly solubility parameters, between dopants and host elements, sequential processing becomes necessary. This approach involves initial host matrix formation followed by subsequent dopant incorporation stages. Such staged synthesis mitigates phase segregation risks while ensuring atomic-level dopant distribution, even in systems with significant lattice mismatch or thermodynamic incompatibility [63,87]. Chemical reduction strategies enable heteroatom doping through controlled solution-phase reactions, including wet chemical reduction, hydrothermal synthesis, and reductive precipitation approaches. This methodology offers distinct advantages in achieving homogeneous dopant distribution via streamlined synthetic protocols. A representative demonstration by Han et al. utilized solvothermal synthesis to fabricate gadolinium-doped CuO x catalysts, where Gd incorporation stabilized Cu+ species and induced lattice expansion effects. The optimized catalyst exhibited exceptional C2+ product selectivity with 81.4% Faradaic efficiency at −0.8 V versus RHE, accompanied by a partial current density of 444.3 mA cm−2. Combined operando spectroscopy and density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed synergistic effects between Gd-induced lattice strain and electronic structure modifications, collectively enhancing multi-carbon pathway activity [35]. Parallel innovations include boron-doped copper hollow fiber electrodes synthesized through phase-transformation-assisted annealing and wet chemical reduction synthesized by Zhang et al. This architecture effectively mitigated electrolyte decomposition and electrode coking issues while maintaining stable CO2 reduction performance [103]. The versatility of chemical reduction methods extends to precursor engineering, where pre-doping of heteroatoms enhances structural stability and modulates electronic properties through strain effects or ligand interactions. Zhou et al. exemplified this approach through a two-step solution synthesis of Pd-doped Cu2O nanocatalysts, subsequently electroreduced to Pd-Cu hybrid systems [104]. Such precisely engineered doping configurations demonstrate significant potential for tailoring catalytic architectures toward optimized CO2RR performance metrics. Electrochemical doping methods provide precise control over dopant concentrations through current modulation while maintaining copper species in desired oxidation states. The galvanic replacement technique enables homogeneous metal incorporation within copper-based catalysts, as exemplified by room-temperature synthesis of dendritic Cu-Sn bimetallic systems synthesized by Li et al [105]. By engineering oxygen adsorption energetics at copper sites, this approach significantly enhanced Faradaic efficiencies and current densities for CO, C2H4, and C2H5OH production across varying overpotential regimes. Electrodeposition represents another versatile doping strategy where deposition duration directly governs dopant loading levels. Zhang et al. demonstrated this capability through uniform palladium distribution across copper nanoparticle surfaces via controlled electrodeposition. Pulse electrochemical protocols further extend this methodology by employing alternating potentials to regulate catalyst nucleation and growth dynamics. Practical implementations include silver-doped copper catalysts fabricated in specialized electrolyte baths and freestanding palladium-copper hybrid systems. These electrochemical approaches enable atomic-level precision in dopant placement while preserving structural integrity under operational conditions [106]. Physical blending techniques achieve elemental doping through mechanical mixing processes such as solution-phase mixing and centrifugal dispersion. These methods offer operational simplicity, minimal equipment requirements, and scalability for industrial applications. Representative implementations include lead-doped Cu2O catalysts synthesized via solution blending synthesized by Ma et al [107], and silver-incorporated Cu2O nanocubes fabricated through a one-pot seed-mediated approach synthesized by Wang et al. Further demonstrating this strategy, Zhang et al. enhanced product selectivity in CO2 reduction by nickel-modifying copper nanowires through controlled interfacial mixing [108]. Thermal processing techniques, encompassing calcination, pyrolytic reduction, and controlled decomposition, enable structural engineering of catalyst systems. These methods facilitate crystalline phase stabilization and vacancy architecture construction. Peng et al. demonstrated that lithium vacancies in Li2CuO2, created via sol-gel synthesis followed by calcination, significantly enhance C–C coupling efficiency. Similarly, pyrolysis-based strategies have been employed to synthesize copper-based precatalysts containing non-metallic heteroatoms, where high-temperature treatment induces controlled defect formation while preserving structural integrity [109]. Collectively, these synthetic approaches establish robust frameworks for engineering heteroatom-incorporated copper-based systems, effectively enhancing both C2+ product selectivity and catalytic turnover frequencies in CO2RR. Methodological selection requires holistic evaluation of dopant-specific physicochemical properties (ionic radius, electronegativity and valence states) alongside experimental feasibility constraints (temperature windows, precursor solubility, and phase stability). Future research trajectories should prioritize innovative doping paradigms that enable precise regulation of intermediate adsorption energetics and charge transfer kinetics, ultimately advancing toward programmable CO2 conversion systems with optimized EE. 4 Doping strategies for Cu-based catalysts Doping can adjust the electronic structure of materials by altering their chemical and physical properties, thus achieving excellent electrochemical performance. The performance of doped materials depends largely on the doping elements. By introducing foreign elements, effects such as lattice distortion and alteration of electron cloud density can be generated. For example, lattice distortion can create more active sites, while the change in electron cloud density can optimize the adsorption and desorption processes of reactants. Moreover, different elements with various properties can be selected according to requirements, and factors such as the doping amount and doping position can be precisely controlled. In addition, doping also affects the surface morphology of materials, increases roughness and optimizes active sites, and regulates reaction selectivity. Dopant elements are systematically categorized based on their periodic table positions into four primary groups. Noble metal dopants including Au, Ag, Pt, and Pd enhance catalytic activity and stability through their distinctive electronic configurations and superior chemical inertness [110-113]. Main group metals such as alkali metals (Li, Na, and K) and alkaline earth metals (Mg, Ca, and Ba) [72] modulate electronic cloud density and lattice parameters via their defined valence electron structures [114]. Transition metal dopants like iron (Fe), cobalt (Co), nickel (Ni), and zinc (Zn) exhibit d-orbital-mediated electronic interactions with copper hosts, strategically tuning d-band center positions to optimize intermediate adsorption/desorption energetics [115]. Lanthanide series elements (La, Ce, Pr, and Nd) introduce unique 4f-orbital effects that modify surface charge distribution and stabilize metastable copper oxidation states during catalytic cycles. Their special 4f orbital electrons play a unique role in the catalytic process, which can introduce new active sites, enhance thermal stability and anti-poisoning ability. Finally, non-metal doping [116-118], including C, N, O, P, S, etc. These elements can change the surface chemical properties, electronic structure and crystal structure, adjust the acidity and alkalinity of catalysts, and influence the catalytic reaction pathways and selectivity. To systematically evaluate the impact of different doping strategies on electrocatalytic performance, we have summarized and compared key indicators in Table 1 . This table compiles the electrocatalytic performance of copper-based catalysts doped with noble metals, transition metals, main group metals, and non-metals in CO2 reduction, including parameters such as primary products, selectivity, and FE. This visual presentation facilitates direct comparison of performance trends. 4.1 Noble metal doping The incorporation of noble metals introduces distinct electronic configurations that enhance both charge transfer kinetics and interfacial charge redistribution in copper-based catalytic systems. This strategic modification significantly modifies the coordination environment of active sites, thereby optimizing adsorption energetics for critical reaction intermediates while maintaining structural stability under operational conditions. Meanwhile, due to the optimization of the electronic structure, the electron-transfer steps during the reaction process may become smoother. This optimization effectively lowers the reaction overpotential while concurrently enhancing the process efficiency of carbon dioxide electroreduction. 4.1.1 Au doping The incorporation of Au dopants modifies the electronic configuration within Cu-based catalytic systems, shifting the d-band center position while enhancing active site accessibility for CO2 adsorption. This structural reorganization concurrently stabilizes surface-bound *CO intermediates and reduces the energy barrier for subsequent electrochemical transformations. It forms a unique interaction at the interface, which in turn affects the adsorption of reaction intermediates, the reaction pathway, and enhances the activity of active sites, ultimately improving the catalytic performance. Kuang et al. engineered a Cu/Au heterojunction-based bimetallic electrocatalyst demonstrating exceptional CO2 reduction performance [119]. As shown in Fig. 7 a, CO, a critical intermediate for non-formate product formation, displays weaker adsorption on CuAu alloy surfaces relative to pure Cu or Cu/Au interfaces. This observation emphasizes the structural dependence of intermediate binding behavior in catalytic systems. Fig. 7b delineates distinct reaction pathways for OCCO* and HCO* intermediate generation. The Cu/Au interface thermodynamically favors direct CO coupling (ΔG = 0.52 eV), enabling asymmetric OCCO* hydrogenation via the OCCOH* intermediate to selectively produce ethanol. In contrast, pure Cu systems preferentially form ethylene through CHOCHO* intermediate coupling. These mechanistic divergences reveal the heterojunction's unique capacity to steer reaction trajectories toward specific C2+ products. Comparative free energy diagrams (Fig. 7c, d) quantify the potential-dependent pathways for ethylene and ethanol synthesis on Cu/Au versus Cu catalysts. The heterojunction system exhibits reduced energy barriers for ethanol-forming steps, rationalizing its enhanced alcohol selectivity through stabilized transition-state configurations at interfacial sites. The reaction pathway for the generation of C2H5OH on the Cu/Au heterojunction presented in Fig. 7c details the conversion process from CO2 to C2H5OH, further confirming the promoting effect of the special structure formed by Au doping on ethanol generation. Wei et al. synthesized gold nanoparticle-decorated copper nanowires (Au-Cu NWs) via homogeneous nucleation, demonstrating optimal CO2 reduction performance at Au/Cu mass ratios of 0.7/99.3 [120]. This structural configuration enhances C2+ product selectivity and catalytic activity through synergistic mechanisms involving three interconnected processes: surface roughening induced by Au nanoparticles increases active site density, efficient *CO intermediate spillover from Au to Cu sites achieves a theoretical transfer efficiency of 87.2%, and interfacial electron transfer generates electron-deficient Cu species that strengthen *CO adsorption energetics while lowering activation barriers for multi-carbon pathway progression. Valence-band photoemission analysis (Fig. 7e) reveals that Cu99.3Au0.7 NWs exhibit the highest d-band center among the tested materials. This phenomenon correlates with intensified *CO binding. A finding, which is corroborated by in situ Attenuated Total Reflection-Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) studies, confirms that Au doping modifies both electronic configurations and active site distributions. Complementing this work, Ma et al. developed position-selective Cu-grown Au-Cu heterostructures with exceptional CO2RR performance. These catalysts achieve Faradaic efficiencies of 55.5% (C2H4) and 84.3% (multi-carbon products) in H-cell and flow reactor configurations. Operando characterization and computational modeling reveal coexposed 2H-Au and 2H-Cu domains diversify CO* adsorption geometries, promoting intermediate spillover and C–C coupling while reducing ethylene formation barriers. The interfacial synergy between metallic Au and Cu is further evidenced by wavelet-transform EXAFS analyses (Fig. 7f). Cu K-edge spectra confirm dominant metallic Cu phases, while Au L 3-edge data verify interfacial Au–Cu bonding with preserved metallic character in Au domains [134]. In addition, Au doping can alter the crystal structure or lattice parameters of Cu-based catalysts. This, in turn, affects the diffusion rate of reactant molecules on the catalyst surface, accelerating the reaction process. Meanwhile, it may inhibit the agglomeration or sintering of Cu-based catalysts during the reaction, maintaining the high dispersion and activity of the catalyst and ensuring its stability during long-term reactions. In different electrolyte solutions, the stability of Au-doped Cu-based catalysts varies. This change is closely related to the synergistic effect between Au and Cu and the adjustment of the electronic structure. These factors, from different aspects, enrich the theoretical system of the influence of Au doping on the performance of Cu-based catalysts, providing a broader space for thinking in related research and applications. In the field of electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction, the doping of Ag into Cu-based catalysts exhibits unique and outstanding performance. Its mechanism of action is diverse and synergistic, achieving remarkable results with prominent highlights. Overall, Ag doping mainly regulates the electronic structure, surface composition, and active-site characteristics of Cu-based catalysts. Thereby, it precisely controls the adsorption strength and reaction pathways of key intermediates, optimizing and enhancing the selectivity and activity of carbon dioxide reduction products. Notably, through skillfully adjusting the surface composition and applied potential, high-selectivity preparation of various high-value-added products has been achieved, demonstrating the potential value of this type of catalyst in industrial applications. 4.1.2 Ag doping The doping of Ag into Cu-based catalysts demonstrates unique and outstanding performance in the CO2RR, with diverse and synergistic mechanisms of action, yielding remarkable results and highlighting significant features. Generally speaking, Ag doping mainly optimizes and enhances the selectivity and activity of CO2 reduction products by regulating the electronic structure, surface composition, and active-site characteristics of Cu-based catalysts, thereby precisely controlling the adsorption strength and reaction pathways of key intermediates. Notably, through the delicate adjustment of surface composition and applied potential, the highly selective preparation of various high-value-added products has been achieved, demonstrating the potential value of this type of catalyst in industrial applications. Wei et al. focused on the Ag-Cu bimetallic surface alloy and achieved fruitful results. Regarding the control of product selectivity, they first evaluated the product selectivity of ECO2RR by calculating and detecting the FE of products, and then fitted three-dimensional color maps of the FE for C2H/A (i.e., C2H4 and C2H5OH), C1H/A (i.e., CH4 and CH3OH), and CO on the Ag x Cu100− x surface alloy (Fig. 8 a). A detailed exploration of the surface maps extracted from the 3D color maps (Fig. 8b) reveals that on the Cu-rich surface (Ag: 14–34 at%) of Ag x Cu100− x , at cathodic potentials of 0.85 to 1.00 V, CO2 can be highly selectively converted into C2H/A. For example, for Ag16Cu8.4 at a cathodic potential of 0.90 V, the FEC2-H/A is as high as 60.3%. Increasing the surface Ag content (Ag: 27–55 at%) is beneficial for FEC1-H/A at cathodic potentials of 1.00–1.10 V vs. RHE. For Ag43Cu5.7 at 1.10 V vs. RHE, the FEC1-H/A reaches 41.4%. On the Ag-rich surface (Ag: >74 at%) of Ag x Cu100− x , at cathodic potentials of 0.90–1.15 V, there is a stronger selectivity for CO. For Ag88Cu12 at 1.10 V vs. RHE, the FE of CO can reach 74.0%, intuitively demonstrating the powerful regulation of product selectivity by composition and potential intuitively demonstrating the powerful regulation of product selectivity by composition and potential [76]. In situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) was utilized to track reactive intermediates on compositionally regulated Ag-Cu alloy catalysts, providing atomic-scale insights into the mechanistic pathways governing the ECO2RR. This operando characterization technique revealed composition-dependent adsorption configurations of key carbonaceous intermediates during the reaction cascade, providing atomic-level insights into the alloying effect on CO2 activation energetics and C–C coupling propensity. (Fig. 8c, d). On the Cu-rich Ag16Cu84 surface and the Ag43Cu57 surface where Ag/Cu is close to equilibrium, many key intermediates were identified. For example, the vs(C=C) signal at 1561 cm−1 is associated with the formation of the *COCO intermediate, which dominates the selective formation of C2H/A. The vb(C–OH) signal at 1407 cm−1 and the vs(C–OH) signal at 1119 cm−1 confirm the presence of hydroxyl-containing intermediates, which are related to the formation of alcohols. With the increase of the cathodic potential, the peak areas of various intermediates change regularly, reflecting the conversion process of *CO to subsequent reduction substances. On the Ag-rich Ag88Cu12 surface, the detected vs(C–OH) signal implies the presence of the *COOH intermediate, which is consistent with its high CO yield performance, thus clarifying the differences in reaction pathways dominated by different surface chemical compositions. Based on the insights from spectroscopy, the ECO2RR reaction pathways on the Ag x Cu100− x surface depending on the chemical composition are illustrated as shown in Fig. 8e. The Cu-rich surface is conducive to the coupling of *CO-*CO to form the *COCO intermediate, leading to the formation of C2H/A (P1). The Ag/Cu equilibrium surface tends to protonate *CO to generate *CHO, facilitating the production of C1H/A (P2). The Ag-rich surface promotes the desorption of *CO, enabling the highly selective production of CO (P3). Simultaneously, an exploration of the electronic structure of the surface alloy reveals that as the Ag content increases, the alloy surface Ed linearly decreases from 2.54 eV. According to the d-band center theory and the change in the *CO binding energy calculated by DFT, this weakens the *CO binding strength. The transition from strong to weak dominates the subsequent reaction direction and determines the product selectivity. Furthermore, a predominance area diagram was drawn (Fig. 8f). By means of the thermodynamic reaction tendencies corresponding to different potential and composition ranges, theoretical support was provided for controllable selectivity, clarifying the potential and composition “windows” for the highly selective production of each product. Cao et al. took a different approach by constructing an Ag-Cu2O interface catalyst for neutral CO2 electroreduction. A series of Ag-Cu2O catalysts were synthesized through a simple one-pot seed-mediated method (Fig. 8g). X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy (including X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) was used to precisely analyze the electronic state of Cu in Ag-Cu2O-0.10 (Fig. 8h, i), determining that the oxidation state of Cu was +1 and the phase was attributed to Cu2O, laying a solid foundation for subsequent performance interpretation. In the evaluation of CO2RR performance, compared with Cu2O NPs and Ag NPs, the Ag-Cu2O catalyst showed distinct advantages at high current densities. For Ag-Cu2O-0.10, at 650 mA cm−2, the FE of C2+ soared to 73.6%, the FEC2H4 reached 66.0%, the partial current density was 429.1 mA cm−2, and the C2H4 yield was as high as 1334.1 μmol h−1 cm−2. Moreover, the HER was effectively suppressed, and the ratios of C2+/C1 and C2H4/C1 were much higher than those of Cu2O NPs, highlighting the contributions of Ag doping and interface construction in promoting C–C coupling and optimizing product selectivity, as shown in Fig. 8j and k. The synergy between DFT calculations and in-situ characterizations confirmed that Ag doping reduced the free energy of *COOH formation, facilitated the migration of *CO from Ag to Cu sites, increased the CO coverage around the Cu active sites, and enhanced C–C coupling, unlocking the mechanism for the efficient formation of C2H4, as shown in Fig. 8i [121]. In addition to the mechanisms described above, there may be other potential synergistic mechanisms in Ag-doped Cu-based catalysts. From the perspective of crystal structure, the incorporation of Ag atoms into the Cu lattice may fine-tune the lattice parameters, optimize the adsorption and diffusion channels of reactants, and accelerate the reaction process. Regarding long-term stability, the presence of Ag may inhibit the agglomeration, corrosion, and other degradation behaviors of Cu in the electrocatalytic environment. By changing the surface energy and forming an alloy phase, the high activity and stability of the catalyst can be maintained. In terms of electrolyte adaptability, Ag doping may expand the types and concentration ranges of electrolytes suitable for the catalyst. Through its special surface double-layer structure and ion adsorption characteristics, the interaction with the electrolyte can be enhanced, synergistically improving the catalytic efficiency, continuously enriching the theoretical and application values of Ag-doped Cu-based catalysts in the field of carbon dioxide reduction. 4.1.3 Pd doping Palladium-modified copper catalysts have emerged as a focal point in contemporary electrocatalytic research, particularly for multi-carbon product synthesis. This heightened interest stems from the unique capacity of palladium to modulate *CO adsorption energetics at copper interfaces. The exceptional *CO adsorption properties inherent to palladium enable optimal stabilization of this critical intermediate while preserving the active oxidation states of copper during electrochemical processes [122]. A representative investigation by Xie et al. systematically correlated bulk electrolyte pH variations with localized interfacial pH gradients under operational current densities, revealing the dual role of palladium in both intermediate stabilization and charge transfer mediation. These findings demonstrate how strategic incorporation of palladium extends the potential window for C2+ product formation on copper catalysts by simultaneously enhancing *CO surface coverage and suppressing competitive hydrogen evolution pathways (Fig. 9 a, b). They identified that a pH of 2.0 represents an appropriate reaction condition for acidic CO2RR. This is because it can balance the bulk pH and the formation of carbonates, thereby reducing CO2 loss.
