DFT simulations revealed that Pd alloying in Cu matrices elevates CO adsorption density while accelerating carbon-carbon bond formation kinetics. The enhanced CO chemisorption on Pd-Cu surfaces simultaneously reduces H* adsorption strength, suppresses competing hydrogen evolution pathways, and improves multi-carbon compound selectivity, as mechanistically illustrated in Fig. 9c. Guided by this theoretical foundation, a Pd-Cu catalyst was successfully synthesized and demonstrated outstanding performance in experiments. In the constructed non-crossover system (where the crossover of liquid products is less than 0.05%), at a current density of 500 mA cm−2, the FE for the conversion of CO2 to C2+ reached as high as 89%±4%, and the single-pass utilization rate of CO2 for C2+ conversion attained 60%±2% (Fig. 9d) [123]. Zhou et al. designed and synthesized a multi-active-site catalyst in which palladium was atomically dispersed in copper (denoted as Pd-Cu) [104]. The Pd-Cu catalyst exhibited excellent performance for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to C2+ products. Specifically, the Faradaic efficiency (FE) of C2+ products remained at approximately 80.8% even at a high current density of 0.8 A·cm−2 for at least 20 h. Moreover, the FE of C2+ products exceeded 70% at 1.4 A·cm−2. Experiments and DFT calculations (Fig. 9e–i) revealed that the catalyst possessed three distinct catalytic sites, which efficiently promoted CO2 conversion, water dissociation, and CO transformation, respectively, ultimately leading to high yields of C2+ products (Fig. 9j). 4.2 Main-group metal doping In the field of electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction, doping Cu-based catalysts with main-group metals is of great significance. It can regulate the electronic structure to change the charge distribution, optimizing the adsorption of key intermediates. Altering the surface composition can create new active sites or modify their micro-environment, precisely controlling product selectivity. Modifying the geometric and electronic properties of active sites can inhibit side reactions and enhance the FE. This points the way for the development of electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction technology, holds great value in energy conversion and other aspects, is expected to promote industrial upgrading, and contribute to addressing climate change. Through theoretical calculations, Zhang et al. conducted a screening process and discovered that incorporating the Lewis-acid metal Al into Cu could adjust the oxygen-affinity of Cu-based catalysts. This shows potential in facilitating the electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ alcohols. In experimental work, the Al-Cu/Cu2O catalyst was successfully fabricated. This catalyst exhibited outstanding performance in flow-battery tests. The FEC2+ achieved a peak value of 84.5% with exceptional stability, while C2+ alcohol selectivity reached 55.2%. Corresponding operational parameters exhibited a partial current density of 354.2 mA cm−2 and product formation rate of 1066.8 μmol cm−2 h−1. Comprehensive mechanistic studies through multimodal characterization confirmed that aluminum doping strengthened reactive oxygen species (ROS) adsorption on copper substrates while stabilizing the *OC2H5 reaction intermediate. DFT calculations further uncovered the underlying mechanism, indicating that Al doping optimized the binding energies of relevant intermediates. On the Al-Cu/Cu2O model, the free-energy change of the key reaction steps in the ethanol-generation pathway was more favorable than that of the ethylene pathway, and the energy difference reflected the regulatory effect of Al doping on the reaction pathway (Fig. 10 a, b). Fig. 10c indicated that the ethanol desorption energy was lower on this model, further explaining its promotion of ethanol selectivity. Al doping stabilized the Cu+ species, facilitated the breaking of the Cu–C bond during the adsorption of the selectivity-determining intermediate, and inhibited the breaking of the C–O bond, thus promoting the ethanol-generation pathway. Moreover, this strategy could be extended to other Lewis-acid-site dopants, providing important insights into the rational design of catalysts for CO2RR to C2+ alcohols [91]. Peng et al. successfully developed a (111)-facet-oriented nano-Cu2Mg intermetallic compound catalyst (Cu2Mg(111)). A series of characterization methods were used to reveal its structural characteristics. XPS and XANES indicated the existence of electron transfer from Mg to Cu. To gain an in-depth understanding of its electronic structure, an electron localization function (ELF) calculation was carried out (Fig. 10d–f). Comparing the ELF diagram of the Cu2Mg(111) model in Fig. 10d with that of the Cu(111) model, it can be seen that Cu2Mg(111) has special regions with high ELF values at the Cu3-Mg and Cu6-Mg centers. Fig. 10e further shows that the ELF value of Cu in Cu2Mg(111) is lower than that in Cu(111), indicating the formation of Cu+. Fig. 10f shows that the ELF value of Cu3-Mg+ is higher than that of Cu6-Mg+, proving that Cu3-Mg+ contributes more to the electron transfer of Cu+, and the corresponding active catalytic site is Cu3-Mg+. In the electrocatalytic CO2RR test, this catalyst performed outstandingly. At a total current density of 600 mA cm−2, the FE of ethanol was as high as 76.2 ± 4.8%, and the peak partial current density of ethanol reached 720 ± 34 mA cm−2, far exceeding those of traditional Cu2Mg and commercial Cu catalysts. Moreover, it exhibited high FE and energy efficiency under high-current-density electrolysis and had good stability. Through comparative studies with other facets and models, it was found that the surface of Cu2Mg(111) consists of high-density Cu3 and Cu6 rings and subsurface ordered Mg sites, which can increase the *CO surface coverage, reduce the *COCO coupling reaction energy, and stabilize the *CHCHOH intermediate. This is attributed to its unique structure and electronic properties, providing a promising strategy for the electroreduction of carbon dioxide to ethanol at high current densities [124]. Furthermore, Li et al. concentrated on the impact of p-block metal-doped Cu catalysts on the electrocatalytic performance for CO2. Through experimental procedures, a series of p-block metal (including Ga, Al, Ge)-doped Cu catalysts were successfully synthesized. Among these catalysts, the CuGa catalyst exhibited remarkable performance. At a potential of −1.07 V relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode, when the current density reached 0.9 A cm─2, the FE of C2+ could attain 81.5%. Even when the current density was 1.1 A cm─2, it could still maintain a high C2+ production efficiency of 76.9% [125]. To thoroughly investigate the factors contributing to its performance enhancement, theoretical research was carried out. Density functional theory calculations were conducted by building models (Fig. 10). Fig. 10g illustrates the density of states of the Cu 3d/4s orbitals and the CO molecule, as well as their interaction when the CO molecule is adsorbed on the Cu surface. Fig. 10h depicts the corresponding situation on the CuGa surface. By making a comparison, it can be observed that the doping of Ga causes the energy dispersion of the p-π* orbitals formed on the CuGa surface to be wider above the Fermi level. This enhancement in the interaction between the active sites and the CO molecule is favorable for the adsorption of CO. Fig. 10i presents DFT-optimized adsorption configurations of key intermediates on Ga-doped Cu(111) surfaces, indicating Ga doping modifies intermediate adsorption behavior. Theoretical insights suggest Ga-Cu p–d orbital hybridization drives electronic structure reconfiguration, which intensifies *CO intermediate binding via enhanced orbital interactions, lowers the C–C coupling activation barrier, and enriches catalytically active sites. This mechanism elevates C2+ selectivity and demonstrates generalizability in other p-block metal-doped Cu systems (e.g., CuAl, CuGe), delivering C2 Faradaic efficiencies of 77.3% and 75.5% at 0.9 A cm−2, respectively. The orbital hybridization principle establishes a universal design strategy for high-efficiency CO2 electroreduction catalysts. 4.3 Transition metal doping In the field of electrocatalytic CO2RR, the doping of transition metals into Cu-based materials offers significant advantages. Due to their unique electronic layer structures and large ionic radii, lanthanide elements, after doping, can alter the electronic structure, enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2, and also increase the number and types of active sites, which is conducive to the production of high-value-added products. Other transition metals, by virtue of their rich valence states, can form electronic interactions with Cu, optimize electron transport, accelerate charge transfer to improve the reaction rate, and at the same time precisely regulate the coordination environment and electron density of active sites, suppress the hydrogen evolution side reaction, and improve the FE and selectivity of the target products, thus significantly enhancing the CO2RR performance of Cu-based materials. 4.3.1 Lanthanide element doping Doping with lanthanide metals exerts multiple advanced effects in the field of catalysis. By altering factors such as the electronic structure, oxygen vacancy concentration, and crystal structure stability of catalysts, it significantly enhances the performance of various catalysts in numerous key reactions, demonstrating broad application prospects. Fig. 11 a mainly presents the electronic structures and ground-state configurations of rare-earth elements, as well as the variation patterns of ionic radii and valence-state configurations [126]. These characteristics are closely related to the applications of rare-earth elements in materials, providing an important theoretical basis for understanding the impact of rare-earth doping on material properties. Liu et al. developed rare earth-copper mixed-phase catalytic systems, demonstrating that modulating the Sm/Cu ratio in CuSm-O x enables selective switching of CO2 electrolysis products between C2+ compounds and methane. Electrochemical evaluations under 500 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH electrolyte (Fig. 11c) revealed a C2+ Faradaic efficiency of 47.5% for the CuO benchmark catalyst. With the increase of the Sm content in CuSm-O x , the FE of C2+ first increased and then decreased. The FE of C2+ for Cu9Sm1-O x could reach 76%, while for Cu9Sm1-O x , the main product became CH4, and the ratio of the FE of C2+/CH4 changed from 42/1 to 1/50. As shown in Fig. 11b, when the Cu content was high (such as in Cu9Sm1-O x ), the catalyst consisted of CuSm2O4 and Cu phases. Samarium incorporation significantly strengthened *CO adsorption, thereby facilitating carbon-carbon bond formation. Under 700 mA cm−2 operation, the C2+ Faradaic efficiency attained 81%. In Sm-rich configurations (e.g., Cu9Sm1-O x ), the catalyst phase composition comprised CuSm2O4 and Sm2O3 crystallites. Samarium effectively stabilized Cu2+ species while increasing proton donor density, which drove *CO deep hydrogenation toward methane production, achieving 65% CH4 FE at 500 mA cm−2. Combined experimental and theoretical analyses confirmed the structural persistence of CuSm2O4 across varying compositions. Its synergistic interplay with adjacent Cu or Sm2O4 phases created distinct microenvironments that directed CO2RR pathways toward specific products. This phase-engineering approach demonstrated generalizability to other Cu-rare earth systems (La, Pr, and Eu), establishing a versatile design framework for selective CO2 electroreduction catalysts [127]. Feng et al. screened out Gd1/Cu2O with good catalytic potential through theoretical calculations and then prepared the Gd1/CuO x catalyst. As can be seen from Fig. 11e, for Gd1/CuO x under different tensile strains, the ΔG for the conversion of 2CO to OCCO decreased linearly with the increase of tensile strain. The ΔG decreased by 0.3 eV when the strain was 0–2.5%, indicating that tensile strain promoted the formation of C2 products. Fig. 11f shows that during the reduction of CO2 to OCCO, the adsorption and activation of CO2 on the Cu surface were difficult, while on the surfaces of Gd1/CuO x and CuO x , the formation of CO2 was exothermic and easier. The ΔG for C–C coupling on Gd1/CuO x measured 2.16 eV, significantly lower than pure Cu (2.54 eV) and CuO x (3.37 eV). With 2.5% Gd doping, ΔG further decreased to 1.86 eV, suggesting Gd doping-induced lattice strain synergistically enhances C–C coupling efficiency. Computational screening identified optimal electronic configurations in the Gd1/CuO x system that drive CO2-to-C2+ conversion, where the coupled effects of atomic-scale Gd doping and interfacial strain collectively modulate reaction thermodynamics. After preparation, characterization confirmed that Gd atoms were dispersed to stably maintain Cu+ and induce tensile strain (Fig. 11d). Electrocatalytic assessments revealed the FEC2+ of Gd-doped catalyst achieved 81.4% at −0.8 V vs. RHE, with a corresponding partial current density of 444.3 mA cm−2. Over the 0.7–1.0 V potential window, FEC2+ maintained over 80% with stable operation and high product formation rates (1.2–1.5 mmol cm−2 h−1). Combined experimental and computational studies demonstrated that Gd doping-induced lattice strain synergistically stabilized O*CCO intermediates through enhanced orbital interactions and reduced the C–C coupling activation barrier by 0.65 eV, boosting CO2-to-C2+ conversion efficiency by 38% compared to unmodified systems. This strain engineering approach provides critical guidelines for designing advanced CO2RR catalysts [35]. 4.3.2 Doping with other transition metal elements Kim et al. investigated the influence of trace cobalt doping on the performance of Cu-based catalysts by synthesizing a MOF-derived CoCu single-atom alloy (SAA) catalyst. As shown in Fig. 12 a, during the reaction of CoCu SAA, CO2 is adsorbed at the Co atomic sites and is rapidly converted into CO. Although the Co atoms are covered by CO, the electronic structure of the adjacent Cu sites is altered, enhancing the adsorption of CO intermediates and promoting CO dimerization to form multi-carbon products. In Fig. 12b, with the change of the cathode potential, the 0.2% Co-doped CuO catalyst exhibits a significant increase in the partial current density of ethylene (C2H4) at −1.01 V vs. RHE, demonstrating high activity. However, when the Co doping concentration is high (1.0% and above), the j C2H4 decreases. Fig. 12c shows that as the CO2 feed rate decreases, the ethylene yield of all catalysts increases. The 0.2% Co-doped CuO catalyst reaches an ethylene yield of 15.56% at −1.07 V vs. RHE, which is one of the relatively high values in neutral or alkaline electrolytes. This is because a low feed rate relatively increases the CO concentration at the three-phase interface, promoting CO dimerization. DFT calculations indicate that the synergistic effect of the Co atomic sites and the Cu sites near the CO-covered Co sites accelerates the CO2-to-CO conversion, increases the CO coverage, and promotes the selectivity of ethylene over ethanol. In summary, CoCu SAA achieves a high ethylene yield at a low Co doping concentration through a unique tandem catalytic mechanism. This provides a new strategy for the design of CO2RR catalysts, highlighting the importance of using strong CO-binding elements to create tandem sites for improving C2H4 production. It also demonstrates the feasibility of optimizing product distribution by adjusting reaction conditions such as the CO2 feed rate [128]. Chen et al. studied the influence of atomically dispersed Sc doping on the performance of Cu2O catalysts in CO2RR through a series of experiments. The test results at different current densities in Fig. 12d show that in a 1 M KOH electrolyte, within the current density range of 200–800 mA cm−2, the FE of C2 products of the Sc0.09-Cu2O catalyst is significantly higher than that of Cu2O and other Sc-doped catalysts. For example, at 600 mA cm−2, the C2 FE of Sc0.09-Cu2O reaches 71.9%, reflecting the remarkable enhancement of Sc doping on the selectivity of C2 products. To explore the underlying mechanism, in-situ ATR-SEIRAS and DFT calculations were carried out. From the in-situ ATR-SEIRAS spectra in Fig. 12e, f, in a CO2-saturated 1 M KHCO3 electrolyte, there are various characteristic peaks of reaction-related species on the surfaces of Sc0.09-Cu2O and Cu2O, such as *CO3 2−, *COO−, and *COatop By comparison, the peak area of *COatop on the surface of Sc0.09-Cu2O is smaller, indicating a lower CO adsorption energy, which is consistent with the DFT calculation results. Further, from the Gibbs free-energy diagram in Fig. 12g, during the electroreduction of CO2 to *OCCO, the ΔG (0.121 eV) of the CO2 adsorption to form *CO2 step on the surface of Sc0.09-Cu2O is much smaller than that of Cu2O (0.209 eV), meaning that Sc doping promotes the adsorption and activation of CO2. Meanwhile, the ΔG (0.231 eV) of the C–C coupling step (2*CO-to-*OCCO) on Sc0.09-Cu2O is significantly reduced by 1.161 eV compared with that of Cu2O (1.392 eV), indicating that atomically dispersed Sc effectively lowers the energy barrier of C–C coupling. Experimental and theoretical studies clearly illustrate that the atomically dispersed Sc atoms in the Sc0.09-Cu2O catalyst reduce the CO adsorption energy and weaken the energy barrier of the C–C coupling step, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity for C2 products. This provides a theoretical basis and practical guidance for the design of high-performance CO2RR catalysts, demonstrating the great potential of the rare-earth metal Sc in improving the CO2RR performance of Cu-based catalysts [102]. Yin et al. developed a novel hybrid catalyst to enhance the production efficiency of ethylene (C2H4) in ECO2RR. By rationally coupling single-atom Ni anchored on high-specific-surface-area ordered mesoporous carbon (Ni-NAC) with Cu nanowires (Cu NWs) having (100) crystal planes, a hybrid catalyst with cascade catalytic functions (Cu/Ni-NAC) was constructed (Fig. 12h). During the experiment, Ni-NAC and Cu NWs were first synthesized, and various Cu/Ni-NAC catalysts were prepared by mixing them in different ratios. Tests in an H-type electrolytic cell with a neutral electrolyte showed (Fig. 12i) that Cu/Ni-NAC with different ratios had a significant impact on the product distribution. Although Cu/Ni-NAC 2:1 had the highest FE for CO, its FE for C2H4 was less than 10%. Cu/Ni-NAC 5:1 could reach an FE of 50% for C2H4 at −1.4 V vs. RHE, and Cu/Ni-NAC 10:1 produced 23% C2H4 at −1.2 V with a slightly lower FE at high over-potentials. After comprehensive consideration, Cu/Ni-NAC 10:1 was determined to have relatively superior performance. To deeply explore its reaction mechanism, in-situ surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (SEIRAS) was used to confirm that the CO generated by the Ni-NAC module could transfer and accumulate on the surface of Cu NWs to promote C−C coupling. Meanwhile, in-situ XANES analysis in Fig. 12j indicated that the Ni K-edge spectra of Cu/Ni-NAC remained unchanged before, during, and after the reaction, demonstrating the high stability of the single-atom Ni structure. The optimized Cu/Ni-NAC 10:1 catalyst was further tested in an alkaline flow battery. By adjusting conditions such as the electrolyte pH, its FE for C2H4 reached 66% at −0.5 V vs. RHE in 10 M KOH, and the current density remained above 100 mA cm−2 during a 10-hour stability test. In conclusion, the modular design of this hybrid catalyst enables efficient conversion from CO2 to CO and from CO to C2H4 by promoting the cross-module transfer and accumulation of the key intermediate CO. This provides a novel and efficient strategy for the production of ethylene in ECO2RR and is expected to be widely applied in the field of multi-step catalytic reactions [129]. 4.4 Non-metal doping Non-metal doping also plays a unique role and offers distinct advantages in regulating the performance of copper-based materials for the electroreduction of carbon dioxide. Unlike metal doping, non-metal doping influences the carbon dioxide electroreduction reaction mainly by altering the electronic structure of the catalyst, increasing the number of active sites, and adjusting the surface chemical properties. Non-metal doping provides an alternative effective approach to optimizing the carbon dioxide electroreduction performance of copper-based catalysts. Through methods such as nitrogen doping and oxygen doping, it is possible to significantly adjust the electronic properties, surface chemical properties, and reactivity of the catalyst without changing the main structure of the catalyst, thus providing new ideas and methods for the design of efficient and stable carbon dioxide electroreduction catalysts[12]. However, the effects of non-metal doping are also influenced by various factors, such as the doping method, doping amount, and the preparation method of the catalyst. Further in-depth research and optimization are required to achieve better catalytic performance. Zheng et al. successfully prepared a series of heteroatom-modified Cu catalysts (X-Cu, where X = N, P, S, and O) through heteroatom engineering on Cu catalysts. As shown in Fig. 13 a, the FEC2+ of N-Cu electrocatalyst exhibited superior across varying current densities, achieving 73.7% FE at −1100 mA cm−2. Notably, its C2-specific partial current density reached −909 mA cm−2 at −1.15 V vs. RHE, surpassing O-Cu and Cu counterparts by 32%–41%. Comparative analysis in Fig. 13b revealed operational current density (−1.5 A cm−2 at −1.18 V vs. RHE) of N-Cu substantially exceeded control catalysts under equivalent potentials. Density functional theory analyses (Fig. 13c) identified stronger *CO adsorption at bridge/top sites on N-Cu (ΔE ads = −0.45 eV) vs. O-Cu (−0.28 eV) and Cu (−0.17 eV), enabling enhanced *CO surface coverage during high-current operation. This optimized *CO population facilitated efficient C–C coupling while suppressing hydrogen evolution, achieving ampere-level CO2-to-C2+ conversion efficiency. The mechanistic insights establish nitrogen-modified copper systems as promising candidates for industrial-scale CO2 electrolysis [130]. Liang et al. synthesized Cu2O and sulfur-doped Cu2O (S-Cu2O) catalysts for CO2RR. As shown in Fig. 13e, within the potential range of 0.8–1.6 V vs. RHE, Cu2O produced diverse products. Its FE was 36.8% at 0.8 V vs. RHE and varied with the potential, and the FE of C2H4 reached 33% at 1.6 V vs. RHE. In contrast, the main product of 1.5% S-Cu2O was formic acid, and the FE of formic acid was as high as 81.4% at 1.2 V vs. RHE. Fig. 13f demonstrates the 1.5% S-Cu2O catalyst achieved substantially higher formate partial current densities than pristine Cu2O across all tested potentials. Experimental evidence confirmed sulfur-modified Cu2O undergoes cathodic reduction to form active S-adsorbed Cu0 sites that selectively catalyze formate production. Mechanistic DFT simulations (Fig. 13d) revealed distinct adsorption configurations of *COOH and *OCHO intermediates on S-doped Cu(111), with *COOH binding to S atoms and *OCHO anchoring at adjacent Cu sites, accompanied by sulfur migration during adsorption. Charge density difference analysis (Fig. 13g, h) identified strong electronic interactions between *CO2 and S-Cu(111), redirecting reaction pathways. Free-energy profiles (Fig. 13i–j) showed CO formation via *COOH remained rate-limiting on both surfaces, requiring 0.35 eV higher activation energy on S-doped sites. Conversely, the formate pathway exhibited a shifted potential-determining step (*CO2 → *OCHO) with 0.28 eV lower barrier on S-Cu(111). Sulfur doping preferentially stabilized *OCHO intermediates while suppressing *COOH adsorption, thereby enhancing formate selectivity and inhibiting CO/H2 pathways. The consistent agreement between computational predictions and experimental data validates sulfur doping as an effective strategy to regulate CO2RR selectivity through interfacial electronic modulation [131]. 4.5 Electronic modulation, side reactions, and selectivity analysis of Cu-based doped catalyst Cu-based catalysts, with their unique C–C coupling ability, have become core materials for the production of multicarbon (C2+) products via CO2 electroreduction (CO2RR). Their electrocatalytic performance is closely related to electronic structure, surface adsorption behavior, and stability, but there is still room for improvement in terms of selectivity and stability. The doping strategy, by regulating the electronic structure and surface chemical environment, has emerged as a key means to optimize catalytic performance. However, existing studies mostly focus on the performance characterization of single elements, lacking systematic analysis of “commonality-difference-trend”. This section, integrating the latest research progress and based on experimental and theoretical calculations, conducts a critical analysis from the following aspects. 4.5.1 Effects of doping elements/valence states on d-band center, *CO coverage, and C–C coupling energy barrier The CO2RR performance of Cu-based catalysts (such as product selectivity and activity) is closely related to their electronic structure. By regulating d-band center position of Cu, doping elements can optimize surface *CO adsorption energy and C–C coupling energy barrier; effects of different types of doping elements exhibit significant commonalities and differences. Doping elements significantly affect *CO adsorption strength and C–C coupling energy barrier by altering d-band center position of Cu: doping with transition metals (e.g., Ni, Fe, Co), noble metals (e.g., Pd, Au), and nonmetals (P, B) typically shifts d-band center upward, enhancing CO adsorption (ΔG* CO becomes more negative), but excessive adsorption may cause catalyst poisoning. For example, P doping can shift d-band center of Cu-based catalysts to near Fermi level, promoting adsorption and activation of CO2 at Cu1N3 sites [132]. In contrast, doping Cu2O with metal elements (Ag, Sc, and Al) and nonmetals (S, N, and Cl) can shift d-band center downward, reducing *CO adsorption energy and significantly optimizing C–C coupling pathway [133]. Taking Ag doping as an example, it shifts d-band center downward, weakening CO adsorption energy (ΔG* CO rises to −0.4 eV), which causes *CO to desorb easily and form C1 products; when Ag proportion exceeds 10 at%, CO selectivity can reach over 90% [76]. This volcano-type relationship between d-band center and *CO adsorption energy has been widely verified, i.e., moderate adsorption strength is most favorable for formation of C2+ products. Elements of the same main group (such as Ag and Au), though both being noble metals, exhibit differences in their roles: Ag doping tends to reduce the *CO adsorption energy (facilitating CO desorption to form C1), while Au doping may enhance C–C coupling through geometric confinement (beneficial for C2+). This difference stems from subtle variations in atomic radius and electronegativity [133]. In addition, as the valence state of the doping element increases (e.g., from +1 to +3), the electronic modulation effect on Cu is enhanced, the shift amplitude of the d-band center increases, and *CO coverage and C–C coupling energy barrier show regular changes; for instance, higher valence states may more strongly inhibit C–C coupling. 4.5.2 Inhibitory or promotive effects of doping on side reactions The competitive side reactions of CO2RR (hydrogen evolution reaction, HER) and catalyst stability (Cu migration/sintering) are key bottlenecks restricting performance, and doping exerts a bidirectional impact on them. HER is the main competitive side reaction of CO2RR, and doping can either inhibit or promote it by regulating the *H adsorption energy barrier. Doping with main group elements (S, P) or highly electronegative elements (such as N) can increase the *H adsorption energy barrier on the Cu surface. For example, sulfur-modified copper surfaces can not only promote the formation of *OCHO intermediates but also significantly inhibit the adsorption of *H and *COOH, thereby preferentially facilitating the production of formic acid in CO2 electroreduction [130], the inhibition mechanism also includes regulating the interfacial pH to form a local alkaline microenvironment (e.g., N doping increases the HER overpotential to −0.75 V vs. RHE). In contrast, doping with some transition metals (such as Ni) can reduce the *H adsorption energy barrier, exacerbating HER, so the doping ratio needs to be controlled to balance activity and selectivity [135]. Cu is prone to migration and agglomeration during the reaction due to high potential or differences in surface energy (with particle size increasing from 10 nm to more than 50 nm). Doping can stabilize the structure through multiple ways: forming alloy phases [136], introducing strong interactions [137], lattice stabilization [138], and interface engineering [139]. On the contrary, doping with low-melting-point metals (such as In) may form eutectic phases, accelerating Cu migration. The activity of Cu90In10 catalyst decreases by 40% after 50 h of reaction, highlighting the importance of selecting doping elements [140]. 4.5.3 Analysis of negative results and controversial points The effectiveness of doping strategies is not absolute, and some negative results and controversial reports reflect the complexity of the system, which should be viewed rationally. There are controversies regarding the impact of doping on C–C coupling: the research team led by Peican Chen found that the steric hindrance effect of Pd in Cu-Pd alloys increases the distance between CO and CHO, inhibits C–C coupling, and promotes the formation of CH4 (FECH4 = 43.23%) [141], however, studies by a team from the Chinese Academy of Sciences have shown that Pd doping can enhance *CO adsorption by optimizing the d-band center, thereby promoting the formation of C2H4 (FEC2H4 > 50%). This difference may stem from the dispersion state of Pd (single atom vs. alloy) and reaction conditions (neutral vs. alkaline electrolyte) [104]. Some studies have shown that when the electronic effects of Ag and Cu cancel each other out (e.g., Ag43Cu57), the d-band center of Cu shifts by only 0.03 eV, and there is no statistical difference in CO selectivity (54%) compared with pure Cu (51%). This is because the d-electrons of Ag and Cu compensate each other, resulting in no significant change in surface adsorption energy. Experimental data show that in 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte, the CO Faraday efficiency of Ag43Cu57 is 54%, which is within the same error range (± 3%) as that of pure Cu (51%). In-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy and density functional theory calculations confirm that Ag doping did not significantly alter the electronic structure of Cu; the d-band center only shifted slightly, and the CO adsorption energy (ΔGCO) changed little, resulting in no obvious improvement in CO selectivity [76]. 5 In-situ detection technology In the realm of ECO2RR, precisely and real-time detecting the valence-state evolution of catalysts during the process is of fundamental importance for conducting research on the stabilization of oxidation states. Comprehending how doping influences the structure and performance of catalysts has become a crucial aspect. The performance of CO2RR is highly contingent upon three key factors: the composition and structure of the electrocatalyst surface, along with the solid-liquid-gas triple-phase interface. These three factors frequently undergo changes during the reaction. Advanced characterization techniques play an indispensable role in this area of detection. Operando/in-situ characterization methodologies allow real-time monitoring of catalytic systems and reactive intermediates under working conditions, delivering critical insights into dynamic surface reconstructions, interfacial phenomena at electrode-electrolyte boundaries, and transient species evolution. These capabilities prove indispensable for elucidating reaction mechanisms and engineering advanced catalysts. Representative analytical approaches encompass Raman spectroscopy with surface enhancement, infrared absorption spectroscopy utilizing surface enhancement, X-ray photoelectron analysis, XAFS studies, crystallographic X-ray diffraction analysis, and complementary techniques. Fig. 14 illustrates specialized electrochemical cell configurations enabling such operando measurements. These techniques can monitor the dynamic catalytic process in real-time, offering detailed information on multiple aspects such as the microstructure of catalyst, chemical composition, electronic properties, and surface state. This aids researchers in deeply analyzing the mechanism of doping, thereby providing strong support for the design and optimization of high-performance CO2RR electrocatalysts. Consequently, efforts should be directed towards developing advanced in-situ valence-state detection techniques. It is important to note that due to the differences in the principles underlying various in-situ detection techniques, their key performance indicators, such as sensitivity and resolution, vary. Even the design of the associated electrolytic cells has its own unique features, resulting in different compatible application scenarios for each technique. In this section, a concise overview of the aforementioned in-situ detection techniques will be presented, covering their basic principles, characterization objectives, and progressive modifications. 5.1 In-situ Raman In-situ Raman spectroscopy holds a unique and crucial position in the relevant detection field. It can be regarded as a complementary technique to in-situ XRD. By detecting changes in key intermediates, it can explain reaction pathways and mechanisms. High-resolution Raman spectroscopic techniques enable simultaneous tracking of catalyst structural dynamics and identification of transient reactive species throughout catalytic processes. In the exploration of various spectroscopic techniques for catalytic research, in-situ Raman spectroscopy has demonstrated many unique properties and advantages. Firstly, for specific patterns formed due to the lack of a long-range ordered crystalline phase, in-situ Raman spectroscopy can effectively respond and conduct relevant detections. Meanwhile, due to the relatively independent nature of the dipole moment within the target molecule, compared with infrared spectroscopy, the versatility of in-situ Raman spectroscopy has been significantly enhanced, enabling it to detect and analyze different substances in a wider range of scenarios. In addition, in-situ Raman spectroscopy has an important ability, that is, it can be used to collect low-wavenumber vibration signals. These low-wavenumber vibration signals contain rich information about the catalyst structure, which cannot be observed in infrared spectroscopy. Leveraging these advantages, Chen et al. carried out fruitful research. By precisely tracking the intensity change of the characteristic T2g vibration peak of Cu2O under potential fluctuations, they clearly and explicitly explained the influence of the Cu+ content on the selectivity of CO [147]. Xue et al. applied a cathodic potential to the samples. In the three control samples of Cu, Cu97Pd3, and Cu95Pd5, distinct Raman peaks emerged in the range of 2000–2100 cm−1. The spectral feature at 2080 cm−1 was assigned to CO adsorbed at step edges of the Cu substrate, while the adjacent 2045 cm−1 peak originated from terrace-adsorbed CO. Progressive cathodic polarization induced a spectral red-shift of these bands, attributed to the Stark tuning effect under elevated CO surface coverage observed in control samples. Conversely, Cu92Sb5Pd3 displayed attenuated CO adsorption signals, with only residual intensity at 2080 cm−1 under reducing potentials. Complementary analysis revealed enhanced Cu-CO vibrational mode intensity at 360 cm−1 in control catalysts (Cu, Cu97Pd3, Cu95Pd5) compared to the ternary alloy. This collective evidence demonstrates greater CO accumulation on Pd-modified Cu surfaces, correlating with their superior C2H4 production efficiency through facilitated C–C coupling pathways. These spectral data vividly demonstrate the differences in the adsorption behavior of CO intermediates on different catalysts, providing important evidence for understanding the high CO selectivity of the samples and facilitating in-depth exploration of their catalytic mechanisms in the ECO2RR (Fig. 15 a, b) [101]. Operando Raman spectroscopy analysis of Cu and CuGa-II catalysts during CO2RR under varying potentials (vs. RHE) revealed no detectable Cu2O-related vibrational signatures for either system, demonstrating complete reduction of copper species under cathodic conditions. A distinct spectral feature at 529 cm−1 emerged exclusively on CuGa-II, corresponding to primary reaction intermediates adsorbed at active sites, indicative of enhanced CO2 activation capability compared to pure Cu. The 365 cm−1 band, associated with hindered rotational modes of adsorbed CO, persisted on CuGa-II at −0.6 V vs. RHE but vanished on Cu, confirming stronger CO intermediate stabilization on the bimetallic surface. Notably, CuGa-II exhibited two characteristic peaks at 1294 cm−1 (C–H bending) and 1366 cm−1 (C–O stretching) when polarized at −0.3 V vs. RHE (Fig. 15c, d), reflecting stabilized carbonaceous intermediates critical for subsequent reduction steps. The above results can be reasonably interpreted as Ga doping enhancing the activation of CO2 molecules and effectively stabilizing the *CO intermediate, thus promoting the C–C coupling process. This provides crucial experimental evidence for studying the reasons for the improved C2 selectivity of the CuGa catalyst and helps to deeply understand the role of this catalyst [125]. (See Fig 16. ) However, in practical applications, considering that some intermediate substances may have a poor Raman scattering cross-section, the Raman signals generated by these intermediate substances are weak, which is not conducive to effective detection. To address this challenge, the surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) technique based on the local surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect has emerged. This technique can significantly enhance the Raman signal by leveraging the strong electric field generated by the LSPR effect, thereby effectively improving the detectable range, detection sensitivity, and time resolution. In particular, the application of SERS greatly improves the resolution. For CO2RR, Raman and SERS-Raman have demonstrated their unique capabilities. In terms of experimental techniques, for example, the immersion-type tip-enhanced Raman measurement can achieve real-time detection of liquid electrolytes, and the TERS technique can be used for the measurement of opaque catalysts. Many studies have utilized in-situ Raman spectroscopy to explore the role of doped Cu-based catalysts. Although in-situ Raman spectroscopy and its derivative technologies have shown powerful functions in many aspects, they are not without flaws. For instance, in-situ Raman spectroscopy can only detect surface substances, and it faces great difficulties in identifying sub-layer molecules and accurate valence states. Moreover, during the detection process, there often appear some bad signal peaks without clear attribution, and the existence of these bad signal peaks seriously hinders the accurate analysis of Raman spectra, posing certain challenges to relevant research work. 5.2 In-situ infrared The ATR-FTIR technique within Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) has become a powerful tool for detecting various reaction intermediates in the ECO2RR due to its rapid response ability and high sensitivity. For example, in the spectrum of Cu4 measured by Li et al., the broad peak at 1653 cm−1 corresponds to the OH stretching vibration of adsorbed water. Its shift to lower wavenumbers at highly negative potentials is attributed to the Fano resonance and Stark tuning effects, indicating that H2O molecules are activated and consumed to generate protons. The strong peaks at 1261 and 1412 cm−1 are attributed to the OH deformation and symmetric stretching vibrations of the COOH intermediate, respectively. The weak peak at 2063 cm−1 is for the adsorbed CO intermediate, which is rapidly hydrogenated to the CHO intermediate at 1039 cm−1. The peaks at 1473 and 1152 cm−1 correspond to the CH2O and OCH3 species, respectively, and their intensities increase with the potential. Based on these, a possible reaction mechanism for the electrocatalytic methanation of CH4 and CO2 was proposed. Most of the reaction intermediates in Cu8 are similar to those in Cu4, but peaks of the COCHO intermediate at 1332 and 1550 cm−1 appear, indicating the initiation of the C2 pathway. These spectral results vividly demonstrate the evolution of reaction intermediates in the two catalysts during the CO2RR process, providing important evidence for a deep understanding of their reaction mechanisms and helping to reveal the role of CuS dual-sites in promoting the electroreduction of CO2 to hydrocarbon products [148]. In the potential range from −0.9 to −0.1 V vs. RHE, the peaks emerging in each spectrum correspond to different CO2 reduction intermediates. Different from the top-adsorbed CO* only present in commercial fcc Cu NPs and the Au+Cu mixture, the bridge-adsorbed CO* was also observed on fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs. The peaks at approximately 2046 and 1944 cm−1 correspond to the top-and bridge-adsorbed configurations of CO* on the Cu surface, respectively. This unique adsorption configuration may stem from the existence of the unconventional-phase Au-Cu interface, which is conducive to C–C coupling and the subsequent formation of the C2 product. In addition, the peaks of OCCOH* (at approximately 1531 and 1180 cm−1) and OC2H5* (at approximately 1343 and 1148 cm−1) on fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs are more prominent than those on commercial fcc Cu NPs and the Au+Cu mixture, especially the peak of OCCOH* at 1531 cm−1. These intermediates are crucial for the formation of C2H4 and C2H5OH, further confirming the enhanced C–C coupling on fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs. These spectral results indicate that the CO* adsorption configurations on fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs are diverse, and the reaction pathway tends to generate C2 products through enhanced C–C coupling, providing key evidence for a deep understanding of the role mechanism of this catalyst in CO2RR [134]. The operando experiments have significantly contributed to understanding the mechanism by which the co-feeding effect enhances C–C bond coupling, highlighting the potential of tandem catalysts. The operando approach has been essential for elucidating the ECO2RR. It is anticipated that further advancements can be made to improve the efficacy of current technologies, such as Surface or Molecular-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS/MERS), Environmental Transmission Electron Microscopy (ETEM), Photoelectron Emission Microscopy (PEEM), Electron Spin Resonance Spectroscopy (ESR), among other methodologies. 5.3 In-situ XPS In the field of catalytic research, in-situ XPS is a technique capable of quantitatively detecting the valence states of surface active sites. When surface atoms are irradiated by X-rays, their valence electrons emit photoelectrons. The information carried by these photoelectrons is closely related to different atomic species and their chemical environments. Based on this, information regarding the composition, content, and valence states of catalysts can be obtained. However, due to the relatively short mean free path and diffusion path of photoelectrons in the environment, XPS measurements must be carried out in an ultra-high vacuum (UHV) environment. Only in such an environment can the interference of air pollutants with photoelectrons be minimized, effectively enhancing the intensity and sensitivity of photoelectrons. Nevertheless, precisely because of this UHV requirement, it is impossible to detect the CO2RR system under the ideal “in-situ” conditions. Consequently, it can merely be considered as quasi-in-situ XPS. Under the circumstances of this quasi-in-situ detection, the sample under measurement has to be transiently taken out of the applied potential and even the electrolyte environment. This unavoidably gives rise to the concern regarding whether the redox state of the sample will change correspondingly. Given the constraints of the in-situ XPS technique previously mentioned, researchers have effectively conducted surface analysis under near-atmospheric pressure conditions. This was accomplished by isolating the sample chamber from the reaction chamber through the implementation of multiple differential pumping stages and an electrostatic lens system. This methodology is referred to as in-situ ambient pressure XPS (APXPS). Additionally, the dip-pull technique presents another feasible option. Yao et al. conducted a quasi-in-situ XPS study on the B-Cu2O catalyst. It was found that after 60 min of electrolysis, both Cu+ and Cu0 species were present on the surface. After 120 min, a distinct Cu+ peak (at 918.6 eV) was still observed, indicating good stability of the surface Cu+ species (Fig. 17 a). In contrast, as shown in Fig. 17b, for the undoped Cu2O catalyst, after 60 min of electrolysis, the characteristic Cu+ peak (at 918.6 eV) completely disappeared, and a characteristic Cu0 peak (at 916.8 eV) emerged, suggesting that the undoped Cu2O catalyst was completely reduced to metallic Cu during the electrolysis. Through this comparison, these results vividly demonstrate the significant impact of B-doping on the stability of Cu+ species in the Cu2O catalyst, indicating that the introduction of B effectively inhibits the reduction of Cu+ in Cu2O during the reaction. This strongly supports the conclusion regarding the excellent stability of the B-Cu2O catalyst during the electrochemical CO2RR and aids in gaining a deeper insight into how B-doping enhances the performance of the Cu2O catalyst [149]. Recently, Wang et al. conducted an analysis of the quasi-in-situ XPS high-resolution Cu 2p 3/2 and Ag 3d 5/2 spectra for Ag1Cu NW during the electrochemical CO2 reduction at various potentials, including OCV, −0.7 V, and −1.2 V vs. RHE. As illustrated in Fig. 17c and d, under OCV conditions, partially oxidized Cu species were detected in Ag1Cu NW, whereas at −1.2 V vs. RHE, only metallic Cu was observed. This indicates that the oxidized Cu species in Ag1Cu NW can be fully reduced to metallic Cu throughout the reaction, a finding corroborated by the Cu Auger spectra. In terms of the oxidation state of Ag, it was found to be elevated at −0.7 V and −1.2 V vs. RHE compared to OCV conditions, likely due to the adsorption of intermediates onto individual Ag atoms during the CO2RR process. In contrast, quasi-in-situ XPS assessments performed in an Ar atmosphere under identical conditions revealed a similar pattern in the variation of the Ag oxidation state, implying that the intermediates adsorbed on the single Ag atoms of Ag1Cu NW may primarily originate from water rather than CO2. For AgCu NW, at the applied potentials of −0.7 and −1.2 V vs. RHE, both Cu and Ag binding energies exhibited a shift towards more negative values, confirming the involvement of metallic Cu and Ag in the CO2RR. These spectral data vividly display the changes in the surface chemical states of Cu and Ag elements in Ag1Cu NW and AgCu NW during the CO2RR process, providing crucial information for understanding the origin of the differences in reduction selectivity on the two catalysts and helping to reveal their catalytic reaction mechanisms [150]. 5.4 In-situ synchrotron radiation XAS XAS bypasses the limitations of vacuum constraints, enabling operando monitoring of catalytic materials during functional operation. The XAS spectrum comprises two distinct spectral regions: the XANES and extended EXAFS. XANES exhibits element-specific sensitivity, providing semi-quantitative determination of oxidation states through pre-edge and near-edge spectral features. EXAFS can reflect the coordination structure information of the core atom. In-situ XAS has many advantages, such as a wide range of applicable materials and samples and low damage to the catalyst structure. However, due to the use of hard X-rays, the signal represents the average state of the bulk phase, which limits the acquisition of surface information. Currently, there are two main in-situ XAS characterization techniques: in-situ soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy (sXAS) and in-situ grazing-incidence X-ray absorption spectroscopy (GIXAS). sXAS can excite electrons with low energy and detect the surface chemical state of the catalyst with high resolution. GIXAS can control the detection depth within the sub-surface range by adjusting the incident angle. The XANES spectra of the samples measured by Li et al. are shown in Fig. 18 a. When a negative potential was applied, the Cu K-edge energy of Cu4 slightly shifted downward, and this change was also confirmed by its first-derivative spectrum (Fig. 18b). However, even at a strong reduction potential of −1.5 V vs. RHE, the average Cu valence state of Cu4 remained at +0.83, indicating that Cu was chemically stable during the reaction. Moreover, after ceasing the application of the potential, the absorption edge recovered to the high-energy side close to that at the OCV, suggesting that the potential-induced change in the oxidation state was reversible. In the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve, no obvious Cu+ redox peaks were observed during the electrolysis of Cu4, further demonstrating its stability. From the FT-EXAFS spectrum in Fig. 18c, as the potential increased, the amplitude of the Cu–Cu scattering peak gradually increased, implying an enhanced Cu–Cu interaction. Nevertheless, even at −1.5 V vs. RHE, the coordination number of the Cu–Cu bond only increased to 3.4. This indicates that during the reaction, the structure of Cu4 protected by the 2-mercapto-1-methylimidazole (MMI) ligand remained chemically stable, providing an ideal model for subsequent DFT calculations and facilitating in-depth understanding of the electronic structure and reaction mechanism of Cu4 in the CO2RR [148]. Yang et al. studied the in-situ X-ray absorption spectra of core-shell-structured samples. The HERFD-XANES spectrum in Fig. 18d shows that the 7-nm Cu NPs were completely oxidized after storage in air, and their pre-edge energy was the same as that of bulk Cu2O. Under the CO2RR condition at −0.8 V, the NPs transformed into metallic Cu with edge characteristics similar to those of Cu foil, which was consistent with the formation of Cu nanoparticles observed by 4D-STEM. After electrolysis and exposure to air, the NPs were completely re-oxidized to Cu2O. Through the quantitative analysis of the HERFD-XANES spectrum (Fig. 18e), it was found that the fraction of metallic Cu in 7-nm Cu NPs increased from 0 to 100% within 1 h, indicating that their electroreduction was completed in approximately 30 min at −0.8 V. For the 18-nm Cu NPs (Fig. 18f, g), their HERFD-XANES spectrum showed an average composition of approximately 70% metallic Cu core and approximately 30% Cu2O shell. They also transformed into metallic Cu under electroreduction, but to a lesser extent than the 7-nm NPs. After electrolysis and exposure to air, they evolved into a mixed Cu/Cu2O phase. Their electroreduction mainly occurred in the surface Cu2O layer, taking approximately 10 min, and partial re-oxidation gradually occurred within 1 h. EXAFS analysis (Fig. 18h) indicated that after 1 h of electroreduction of the 7-nm Cu NPs, the scattering amplitude of the Cu–Cu peak was significantly lower than that of the standard Cu foil. The fitted average nearest-neighbor Cu–Cu coordination number was approximately 8, indicating the presence of low-coordination Cu sites. After 4 h, the coordination number approached 12 of the Cu foil, possibly due to the continuous aggregation/coalescence of smaller Cu nanoparticles, while low-coordination sites still existed in the steady-state structure. Finally, by correlating the relative fraction of active Cu nanoparticles in Cu NP clusters of different sizes with the C2 FE (Fig. 18i), it was found that a higher fraction of active Cu nanoparticles led to a higher C2 selectivity. For example, the C2 selectivity of the 7-nm Cu NP cluster (100% Cu nanoparticles) was six times that of the 18-nm Cu NP cluster (32% Cu nanoparticles). These results comprehensively reveal the relationship between the structural evolution and catalytic performance of Cu nanocatalysts during the CO2RR process, providing important evidence for in-depth understanding of the active sites and reaction mechanism of Cu-based catalysts [151]. In terms of time resolution, the previous sampling time of minutes posed a significant challenge for experimental observations in transient and metastable states. It was difficult to capture the detailed information of those instantaneous changes and metastable states. To overcome these limitations, investigators pioneered a continuous photon energy modulation approach, supplanting conventional discrete energy stepping methodologies, thereby enabling the development of XAS with millisecond temporal resolution. With this new technology, the spectral acquisition speed has been significantly increased to 10 milliseconds, creating better conditions for capturing rapidly changing experimental phenomena. In catalytic reactions, especially during frequent potential alternations, if the fluctuations in the surface chemical state can be tracked in real-time, a deeper understanding of the catalytic mechanism can be achieved. The ongoing advancement of synchrotron light sources has catalyzed the emergence of cutting-edge operando X-ray spectroscopic methods, including High-Energy Resolution Fluorescence-Detected XAS (HERFD-XAS), X-ray Emission Spectroscopy (XES), and Resonant Inelastic X-ray Scattering (RIXS). These techniques leverage the unique properties of synchrotron radiation to enable real-time, atomic-scale monitoring of catalytic systems under working conditions. They can provide more detailed electronic structure information, effectively compensating for the deficiencies in spatial and time resolution of traditional in-situ XAS. Therefore, they are regarded as having great development potential in the future research field of oxidation-state protection, and are expected to bring new breakthroughs and progress to related research. 5.5 In-situ XRD In the principle of XRD, the atomic lattice possesses the characteristic of a periodic arrangement. This characteristic enables the atomic lattice to function as a diffraction grating that is accountable for the mutual interference of X-rays. Within this system, lattice planes that have a consistent spatial distribution are capable of elastically reflecting X-rays at certain specific angles. As a result, a strong diffraction pattern is formed, and this pattern is closely associated with the lattice parameters of the material. According to the above principle, the in-situ XRD technique has a distinctive analytical capability. It is able to analyze the changes in the crystal structure of catalytic materials that occur over time under various electrolysis potentials. Additionally, it can offer information regarding crystal phases, crystallinity, the orientation of materials, lattice defects, and other relevant aspects. For example, Li et al. used the in-situ XRD technique to monitor the structural changes of the Cu2O/CuO catalyst during the CO2RR. As the reaction progressed, they found that the characteristic peaks of CuO gradually disappeared, while the diffraction peaks of Cu2O persisted. From these observations, it can be reasonably inferred that during this reaction, the Cu+ sites remained in a stable state [152]. In the research of Lei et al., in-situ XRD study of Cu2(OH)2CO3, Cu(OH)2, and CuO nanocrystals is shown in Fig. 19 a, for Cu2(OH)2CO3 at the optimal C2+ production potential of −1.05 V vs. RHE, its characteristic peaks gradually diminished within the initial 45 min of the reaction. At the same time, after 15 min, the intensities of the (111) and (200) peaks of metallic Cu increased. Throughout the entire process, no diffraction peaks associated with Cu hydroxides or oxides were detected, which implies that if these substances were present, they did not form crystalline phases. The reduction time of Cu2(OH)2CO3 shortened as the potential became more negative. Cu(OH)2 (Fig. 19b) showed similar behavior. At a potential of −1.08 V versus RHE, its strongest peak (130) completely vanished after 60 min, even though metallic Cu had already emerged within 15 min. Regarding CuO (Fig. 19c), it quickly and completely transformed into metallic Cu within the first 15 min of the CO2RR, indicating that its electroreduction kinetics were faster compared to those of the previous two materials. Despite the fact that the starting materials had different grain sizes, the grain sizes of the Cu obtained from the three precursors were comparable (around 11 nm). This phenomenon likely originates from synergistic effects of lattice contraction and structural fragmentation. Notably, the Cu nanocrystals synthesized from Cu2(OH)2CO3 and Cu(OH)2 precursors exhibited angular displacements in XRD patterns relative to bulk Cu reference foil, revealing residual lattice strain. Specifically, under −1.05 V vs. RHE operation, Cu(111) and (200) diffraction peaks for Cu2(OH)2CO3 derived Cu shifted by 0.25° and 0.39° toward lower 2θ values, respectively, translating to 0.55% and 0.72% tensile lattice expansion (Fig. 19d). These strain magnitudes displayed minor potential-dependent variations. Similarly, Cu(OH)2-derived Cu maintained substantial tensile strain (0.42%–0.47%) during CO2RR. Conversely, CuO-derived Cu showed negligible peak deviations from the reference across potentials, despite comparable crystallite dimensions to other precursors. All operando XRD measurements underwent liquid-phase background correction using reference standards to mitigate electrolyte-induced peak shifting artifacts. These results indicate that in-situ XRD can reveal the structural transformation, electroreduction kinetics of the precursors during the CO2RR process, and the lattice strain of the derived Cu, providing important evidence for understanding the active species and performance differences of the catalysts [22]. Li et al. studied the XRD patterns of the prepared Cu2O-O and hydroxyl-functionalized Cu2O catalysts. As can be seen from the Fig. 19e, the prepared catalysts exhibited typical characteristic peaks, and no peaks related to metallic Cu were observed. This indicates that under the current synthesis conditions, glucose as a reducing agent can effectively convert Cu2+ to Cu2O without further reducing Cu2O to metallic Cu. By comparing with the standard patterns, the crystal structures of the prepared catalysts were further confirmed, providing important evidence for studying the relationship between the structure and performance of the catalysts and facilitating the understanding of the role of hydroxyl-functionalization in the Cu2O catalyst for the CO2RR [153]. Although these advanced techniques have shown great potential and application value in many aspects, up to now, they have not been widely used in the study of the oxidation-state stability of the CO2RR. However, they still have broad application prospects and are expected to provide strong technical support for subsequent related research. In-situ XRD has demonstrated unique value in the relevant research field and is expected to open up new perspectives for mechanistic analysis. However, in-situ XRD itself also has some technical limitations. It has strict requirements for long-range ordered crystal structures, which makes it difficult to directly and accurately identify the valence state of materials and unable to precisely provide the response signals of amorphous materials. These limitations restrict its application in some specific research scenarios to a certain extent. At the same time, in-situ XRD has the significant advantage of high-time resolution. With this feature, it can quickly obtain the required data in a short time. Precisely because of this advantage, in-situ XRD can be regarded as a highly effective technique for revealing the dynamic evolution process of catalysts under high-reaction rates, providing strong support for in-depth exploration of the changes in catalysts during rapid reactions. 5.6 DEMS In the field of electrochemical research, DEMS technology plays a crucial role based on specific principles. During an electrochemical reaction, the volatile products and intermediates generated on the electrode surface enter the connected mass spectrometer. By accurately measuring their mass-to-charge ratios and ion currents, highly sensitive quantitative analysis of the types and quantities of gases produced by the electrochemical reaction can be achieved, providing core data for exploring the mechanism of electrochemical reactions. Based on this principle, DEMS can monitor in real-time the changes of volatile substances in electrochemical reactions. In the research of fuel cells, it can track the changes in water and impurity gases generated during the hydrogen oxidation reaction. Through data analysis, insights can be gained into the reaction efficiency of the fuel cell, the activity of the catalyst, and the occurrence of side reactions, providing crucial support for performance optimization. However, in practical applications, DEMS has limitations. It cannot directly detect non-volatile reaction products or intermediates, and thus may miss key information in the study of electrochemical reactions involving such substances. At the same time, the detection results are affected by factors such as background gases, the resolution of the mass spectrometer, and the state of the electrode surface, which affects the accuracy of the data and poses difficulties for inferring the reaction mechanism. In electrochemistry, in-situ DEMS has significant advantages. Traditional methods struggle to obtain details of the reactions between electrode materials and electrolytes during battery charging and discharging. In-situ DEMS, on the other hand, can monitor in real-time the gas changes inside the battery, such as hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and other gases generated during the charging and discharging of lithium-ion batteries. Based on this, the situation of side reactions can be inferred, which helps to improve the safety and cycle life of the battery. Ye et al. utilized DEMS to investigate the electrochemical mechanism of Cu-based materials. Fig. 20 a and b display the carbon dioxide streamlines in the cathode chamber of a custom-made DEMS cell at different inlet flow rates (5 and 128 mL min−1) through three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics simulation. Under a fixed applied current density of 7 mA cm−2, CO2 conversion rates were determined through product distribution analysis of the electrochemical reduction process. In low-flow regimes (5 mL min−1, Fig. 20a), cathodic CO2 concentration plummeted from bulk-phase 33 to ∼14 mM, potentially constraining both CO2RR current density and multi-carbon product selectivity. Conversely, high-flow operation (128 mL min−1, Fig. 20b) enabled rapid reactant replenishment, sustaining localized CO2 levels >30 mM. Comparative analyses in Fig. 20c–d illustrate averaged CO2 concentration profiles versus operational current density and electrode proximity under contrasting flow velocities. These data representations confirm substantially alleviated mass transport limitations under 128 mL min−1 flow conditions. The thickness of its hydrodynamic boundary layer is approximately 30 μm, which is much smaller than that of approximately 100 μm at a flow rate of 5 mL min−1. These results indicate that the flow rate has a significant impact on the carbon dioxide concentration distribution near the cathode, thereby affecting the performance. It provides important information on the carbon dioxide mass transfer in the research and helps to optimize the reaction conditions to improve the reaction efficiency and product selectivity [154]. In the study by Ma et al., Fig. 20e presents the in-situ DEMS spectra of CO production during the CO2RR for fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs, commercial fcc Cu NPs, and the Au+Cu mixture. During the linear sweep of the potential from 0 to −1.3 V (vs. RHE), peaks related to CO were detected. The results show that the onset potential of CO on fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs is between that of the Au+Cu mixture and commercial fcc Cu NPs, indicating that the combination of Au and Cu components helps to reduce the over-potential for CO formation. The delay in the appearance of CO on fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs compared to the Au+Cu mixture may be due to the spill-over of CO from the Au domain to the Cu domain. For the production of C2H4 in Fig. 20f, fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs exhibit the least negative onset potential, followed by the Au+Cu mixture, and then commercial fcc Cu NPs. These findings further reveal the importance of the formation of the unconventional-phase Au-Cu interface for the formation of C2 products on fcc-2H-fcc Au-Cu JNSs. By using in-situ DEMS technology to monitor the substance changes in real-time during the reaction process, it provides crucial evidence for a deep understanding of the role mechanism of this catalyst in the CO2RR [134]. Despite the continuous development of DEMS, it still faces challenges. In complex electrochemical reaction systems, the presence of multiple volatile substances may lead to the overlap of mass spectrometry peaks, increasing the difficulty of data analysis. The detection sensitivity for trace volatile substances also needs to be improved to meet the needs of in-depth research. However, with technological advancements, DEMS is expected to play a more crucial role in the field of electrochemical research, accurately and comprehensively revealing the microscopic processes and mechanisms of electrochemical reactions, and promoting the in-depth development of related research. 5.7 EC-SPM Electrochemical Scanning Probe Microscopy (EC-SPM) encompasses a class of scanning probe microscopy techniques operating under electrochemical environments (e.g., in electrolyte solutions or under applied potentials). Its core capability lies in enabling nanoscale characterization under electrochemical conditions. Different EC-SPM techniques focus on distinct dimensions of information, such as morphology, mechanics, electrochemical activity, and potential, based on variations in the interaction mechanisms between the probe and the sample (e.g., tunneling current, force, electrochemical activity). Collectively, they form a powerful toolkit for investigating microscopic processes at the electrode/electrolyte interface. Based on differences in probe-sample interaction mechanisms and detected signals, EC-SPM primarily includes Electrochemical Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (EC-STM) and Electrochemical Atomic Force Microscopy (EC-AFM), among others. EC-STM is an extension of Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM) to electrochemical environments. Its core principle is as follows: in an electrolyte solution, a conductive probe (typically a metal tip such as Pt or W) and the electrode sample act as two ends of a tunnel junction. After applying a bias voltage, when the distance between the tip and the sample surface approaches the nanoscale, electrons tunnel through the gap to form a tunneling current via the tunnel effect. By maintaining a constant tunneling current and scanning the probe, atomic-resolution topographic images of the sample surface can be obtained. EC-STM is characterized by ultra-high resolution (down to the atomic scale) and is suitable for structural characterization of conductive electrode surfaces (e.g., metals, conductive oxides). It enables real-time monitoring of dynamic changes in surface atomic arrangements, adsorbed species, and redox layers during electrochemical processes (e.g., metal electrodeposition/dissolution, surface reconstruction). Key advancements in electrocatalysis enabled by EC-STM include atomic-level insights into catalyst surface structures, the binding and transformation of reactants at catalytic sites, and the structural evolution of active sites during electrocatalytic processes. Fig. 21 a illustrates the schematic of EC-STM for electrocatalytic research [155]. EC-STM studies have successfully validated long-standing controversial mechanisms and uncovered unexpected surface processes. Currently, numerous critical surface electrocatalytic processes remain poorly understood, and EC-STM holds promise for addressing these issues and contributing significantly to the advancement of electrocatalysis. Based on the tunneling current principle, EC-STM allows real-time observation of atomic arrangements on electrode surfaces, defect evolution, and dynamic distribution of adsorbed species (e.g., *CO intermediates), thereby revealing the formation and annihilation of active sites. As shown in Fig. 21b, Kim et al. utilized operando EC-STM to observe that a polycrystalline Cu electrode, maintained at a fixed negative potential of −0.9 V (vs. SHE) during CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) in 0.1 M KOH, undergoes gradual surface reconstruction: Cu(111) forms within the first 30 min, followed by Cu(100) after another 30 min, with no further surface transformation occurring thereafter. This result reveals the dynamic nature of heterogeneous electrocatalyst surfaces and clarifies the intrinsic correlation between their structure, composition, and reaction activity [156]. The performance of a catalyst largely depends on the atomic structure of its active sites. In an electrochemical environment, at CO oxidation potentials, OH− and CO adsorb on the Cu(111) surface, causing Cu atoms to detach. In a CO-saturated electrolyte, the detached Cu atoms are stabilized by binding to CO, with their surface concentration increasing continuously and aggregating to form nanoclusters (Fig. 21c) [155]. In contrast, in a CO-free electrolyte, adsorbed Cu atoms are unstable and rapidly aggregate at step edges. Under CO2 electroreduction (CO2RR) conditions, CO generated from the catalytic reaction pulls Cu atoms from the Cu(100) surface, leading to the formation of nanoclusters (Fig. 21d) [155]. Given the widespread application of Cu in CO electrooxidation and CO2 electroreduction, these metal nanoclusters formed during surface structural evolution, acting as active sites, exert a significant impact on catalytic performance. EC-AFM integrates atomic force microscopy (AFM) with an electrochemical system. It employs a micrometer-scale tip at the end of a microcantilever, characterizing nanoscale topographic changes (e.g., catalytic layer thickness, particle growth) and variations in mechanical properties (e.g., elastic modulus) of electrode surfaces by measuring the mechanical interactions between the probe and the sample. A key advantage of EC-AFM is its broad applicability: it can characterize not only conductive electrodes (e.g., metals, carbon materials) but also insulating or semiconducting materials (e.g., catalyst coatings, polymer membranes). Furthermore, through extended modes (e.g., contact mode, tapping mode, force curve mode), it can simultaneously acquire information on surface topography, mechanical properties (e.g., hardness, adhesion), and electrical properties (e.g., surface potential), making it suitable for studying surface morphological evolution (e.g., catalyst particle agglomeration, dissolution) or changes in interfacial physical properties during electrochemical processes. Wang et al. employed single-crystal electrochemical methods to compare the CO2RR activity of flat and rough Au(111) surfaces in CO2-saturated 0.1 M NaHCO3 electrolyte. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were recorded for both flat and rough Au(111) surfaces after maintaining them at a potential of −0.6 V for 3 min. AFM-SECM (Atomic Force Microscopy-Scanning Electrochemical Microscopy) was used to probe the CO2RR activity of flat and rough Au(111) surfaces (Fig. 21e), confirming that the CO2RR activity of rough Au(111) surfaces is significantly enhanced [157]. In-situ electrochemical scanning probe techniques have become indispensable tools for investigating electrochemical mechanisms by resolving dynamic interfacial processes at the atomic scale. In the field of CO2 reduction, they have advanced the design of high-efficiency catalysts by revealing active site evolution, intermediate behavior, and interfacial mass transfer mechanisms. Looking forward, with improvements in resolution, the development of multi-technique coupling (e.g., integration of STM with high-pressure and electrochemical cells, as shown in Fig. 21f and intelligent data analysis, in situ EC-SPM will play a greater role in energy catalysis, electrosynthesis, and other fields, contributing to the achievement of carbon neutrality goals [158]. 5.8 In-situ characterization combination techniques In the continuous deepening process of electrochemical research, in-situ combined techniques have gradually emerged, providing a more comprehensive and accurate means for in-depth understanding of electrochemical reaction mechanisms. Take the combined technique of in-situ XRD and DEMS as an example. XRD can finely analyze the crystal structure of materials, providing key information such as crystal phases, lattice parameters, crystallinity, and lattice defects. On the other hand, DEMS focuses on detecting the volatile substances generated during electrochemical reactions, including reaction products and intermediates, and enables highly sensitive quantitative analysis of these substances. When the two are combined, a powerful synergistic effect is demonstrated in the study of the carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR). For instance, when exploring the performance of Cu-based catalysts, XRD can monitor in real-time the evolution of the crystal structure of the catalyst under different electrolysis potentials, determining whether there are phase transitions, lattice distortions, etc. Meanwhile, DEMS can detect the changing trends of gases such as hydrogen, carbon monoxide, and carbon dioxide generated during the reaction. The generation of these gases is closely related to the changes in the crystal structure of the catalyst. Through the synchronous analysis of XRD and DEMS data, a deeper understanding of the internal relationship between the catalyst structure and reaction performance can be achieved. The catalytic activity of different crystal phases and the root causes of differences in product selectivity can be clarified, thus providing a comprehensive and precise guiding direction for optimizing catalyst design. The combination of in-situ Raman and an electrochemical workstation is also an important in-situ combined approach. Raman spectroscopy can detect the molecular vibration modes of materials, providing molecular-level structural information, especially being highly sensitive to the adsorption states of species on the catalyst surface, the formation and breaking of chemical bonds, etc. During the electrochemical reaction, by integrating the precise control and measurement of parameters such as potential and current by the electrochemical workstation, dynamic monitoring of the reaction process can be realized. For example, in the study of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), in-situ Raman can observe the adsorption and transformation processes of oxygen species on the catalyst surface. As the potential changes, specific Raman peak positions and intensities will change, corresponding to the generation and consumption of different oxygen adsorption states and reaction intermediates. At the same time, the current changes recorded by the electrochemical workstation reflect the changes in the reaction rate. Combining the two can clearly depict the microscopic reaction process on the catalyst surface during the ORR, revealing the rate-determining step of the reaction and the action mechanism of the active sites of catalyst, providing a strong theoretical basis for the development of efficient oxygen-reduction catalysts. Operando ATR-SEIRAS characterization of the Cu/Ni-NC catalyst in acidic phosphate buffer (Fig. 22 a) revealed distinct interfacial phenomena. The 1633 cm−1 positive band was assigned to surface-adsorbed H2O molecules, while the weak 2118 cm−1 negative signal corresponded to linear C≡O stretching vibrations (CO1) in CO2, indicating CO2 adsorbate depletion. A prominent 1492 cm−1 positive feature under high polarization potentials marked carbonate species generation, resulting from rapid interfacial H+ consumption inducing localized pH elevation and enabling OH−-mediated CO2 neutralization. Under neutral conditions (Fig. 22b), spectral signatures included CO1 vibrations (2125 cm−1), H–O–H bending (1627 cm−1), and a broad 1215 cm−1 feature identified as the carboxyl (COOH*) intermediate. This spectral evolution suggests rapid CO2 − protonation on Cu/Ni-NC surfaces, with carbonate absorption intensifying at cathodic potentials. At the same time, the in-situ ATR-SEIRAS measurements of the Ni-NC sample demonstrate that the addition of Cu promotes the CO2RR process at the Ni sites. Because the CO1 signal of Ni-NC in the acidic medium is weak, and the COOH signal in the KHCO3 aqueous solution is weak, which means that CO2 is consumed more rapidly on Cu/Ni-NC and *COOH is adsorbed more strongly. These in-situ ATR-SEIRAS measurement results provide important evidence for a deep understanding of the CO2RR mechanism of the Cu/Ni-NC catalyst under different pH conditions, helping to reveal the formation and transformation processes of key intermediates during the reaction [135]. Fig. 22c shows the in-situ EELS spectrum of Cu SA/F-GDY during the electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction tested by Zou et al., the EELS spectrum of the Cu L 3-edge for pristine Cu SA/F-GDY was analyzed before the application of potential. The spectrum showed a higher near-edge position (approximately 932.8 eV) compared to that of Cu SA/Ome-GDY. This suggests that the Cu SA/F-GDY sample has a higher oxidation state, which is consistent with findings from XPS and XAFS analyses. During the CO2RR, as the potential gradually increases from 0.6 to 1.0 V, the Cu L 3-edge shifts to lower energy, indicating a decrease in the valence state of Cu at the catalytic center. At 1.0 V, a comparison of the EELS spectra reveals that the near-edge position of Cu SA/F-GDY (approximately 931.9 eV) remains higher than that of Cu SA/Ome-GDY (approximately 931.2 eV). This observation implies that the introduced functional groups can fine-tune the electron density of the Cu center, even under catalytic conditions. It suggests that the positive charge state of the Cu center in Cu SA/F-GDY is preserved, which is a crucial factor for enhancing CO2RR activity. Furthermore, the EELS spectra of the O K-edge recorded for Cu SA/Ome-GDY and the F K-edge for Cu SA/F-GDY show almost identical profiles under different applied potentials, indicating that the introduced functional groups remain stable during electrolysis.
