These in-situ EELS results provide valuable insights into the changes in electronic structure of Cu SA/F-GDY during the CO2RR process, helping to clarify the relationship between its catalytic activity and electronic structure, as well as the regulatory effect of functional groups on the electronic state of the Cu center [159]. Fig. 22d–g show the changes in the scattering spectra of copper nanowires with different silver modification amounts (Cu100− x Ag x ) in the in-situ GAXS experiments as the applied potential changes, as tested by Chang et al. The experiment used an 18 keV synchrotron radiation source, and the scattering intensity was recorded in color-coding. For the copper nanowires (Fig. 22d), the characteristic scattering peaks at q values of approximately 3.01 and 3.48 Å−1 can be attributed to the Cu (111) and Cu (200) crystal planes. Throughout the potential range, its GAXS spectrum shows almost no change, indicating that the crystal nanostructure of the metallic copper nanowires is stable during the electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction. The Cu89Ag11 nanowire catalyst (Fig. 22e) also exhibits similar stability, and its characteristic GAXS peaks related to the Ag (111) and (220) crystal planes can maintain their initial states under actual CO2RR conditions. However, the Cu68Ag32 nanowires (Fig. 22f) show significant changes under the action of the cathodic potential. When the cathodic potential is less than −0.55 V vs. RHE, significant broadening occurs in the Cu(111) and (200) crystal planes, and at the same time, the intensities of the characteristic peaks of Cu and Ag decrease. This indicates that a structural reconstruction occurs on its surface from a phase-separated bimetallic nature to a partially Cu-Ag bimetallic alloy, and this reconstruction basically remains unchanged after the potential is released, showing irreversibility. As for the Cu40Ag60 nanowire catalyst (Fig. 22g), throughout the cathodic reaction process, the characteristic GAXS peaks of Cu and Ag maintain their initial characteristics and positions without significant changes. These results indicate that the structural dynamic reconstruction of Cu68Ag32 nanowires during the CO2RR process is different from that of other samples, which may be the reason for its excellent activity and selectivity, providing important evidence for a deep understanding of the mechanism of this catalyst in the CO2RR [146]. In addition, the combination of in-situ Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) and other electrochemical characterization techniques is also of great value. TEM can directly image the microstructure of materials at the atomic scale, observing detailed information such as the morphology, size, lattice fringes, and atomic arrangement of nanoparticles. When combined with potential-control techniques, the structural changes of catalysts can be observed in real-time under the actual working conditions of electrochemical reactions. For example, in the study of the charge-discharge process of lithium-ion battery electrode materials, in-situ TEM can clearly show the lattice expansion and contraction of materials during the insertion and extraction of lithium ions, as well as the formation and evolution of possible phase transitions and structural defects. Combining with other electrochemical testing methods, such as cyclic voltammetry and galvanostatic charge-discharge tests, a comprehensive understanding of the structural stability, capacity fading mechanism of electrode materials during cycling, and their interaction with the electrolyte can be obtained, providing crucial micro-structural information and performance optimization strategies for the design of high-performance lithium-ion battery electrode materials. Although significant progress has been made in in-situ combined techniques, they still face some technical challenges and difficulties. For example, the instrument compatibility of different characterization techniques needs to be further optimized to ensure stable and efficient operation during combination and avoid interference with each other. The synchronous acquisition and analysis of data also require more sophisticated algorithms and software support to quickly and accurately extract valuable information from a large amount of multi-source data and reveal the complex mechanisms of electrochemical reactions. However, with continuous technological innovation and breakthroughs, in-situ combined techniques are expected to play a more crucial role in future electrochemical research, providing strong technical support for solving key problems in fields such as energy conversion, material synthesis, and environmental remediation, and promoting the rapid development and progress of related disciplines. 6 Theoretical calculation of doped catalysts Theoretical calculations of ECO2RR are mainly used to deal with energy and force in the system, aiming to explore the thermodynamic quantities in the equilibrium state, the evolution of the non-equilibrium system and its properties under stimulation. However, since the calculations need to involve a large number of atoms and electrons, which are too huge to handle, it is necessary to simplify the actual system in typical theoretical calculation studies. This relies on the theoretical framework of “descriptor-based method”, whose basic elements include adsorbates, adsorption energy and adsorption potential, and also involve the Sabatier principle of traditional heterogeneous catalysis and so on. Heterogeneous catalysis is extremely important in ECO2RR. The accelerating effect of catalysts on reaction activity and selectivity affects their application value. The development of efficient catalysts is the key to industrialization. However, the design of traditional catalysts mostly relies on the trial-and-error model. Most research achievements are often based on the intuitive judgment of researchers, and even in some cases, on chance, lacking systematic logic and efficient screening methods. The current development of computing power and high-throughput methods has created the conditions for intelligent and efficient screening, thus leading to the emergence of typical calculation descriptors such as volcano plots and free energy diagrams in different application scenarios of ECO2RR. They are not only general descriptors, but also effective means for screening catalysts [148]. For example, in the doping catalysis of heterogeneous catalysis, the volcano plot is constructed with adsorption energy and activity-related parameters, which can intuitively show the relationship between the two and provide a basis for screening efficient catalysts. The free energy diagram can present information such as reaction paths and kinetic barriers, helping to determine the rate-determining step to increase the reaction rate and predict product selectivity. Machine learning methods can handle complex relationships and predict catalyst performance more accurately based on a large amount of data. These descriptors and calculation methods are of great value for understanding and designing more efficient ECO2RR catalysts. 6.1 Volcano-type plots In the field of electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction, apart from reaction activity, selectivity is also a crucial limiting factor in evaluating the performance of efficient electrochemical carbon dioxide catalysts, and it is significantly influenced by reaction intermediates. Against this backdrop, the volcano plot has emerged and has become one of the most powerful tools for studying reaction intermediates and depicting possible reaction pathways. In the system constructed by the volcano plot, a good correlation can be established between reaction activity and the adsorption energy of intermediates, providing a clear perspective of quantitative relationships for in-depth exploration of relevant catalytic processes. It is particularly worth noting that the volcano-plot approach is essentially a quantitative interpretation of the classic Sabatier principle. It provides extremely powerful guidance for catalyst screening. It clearly indicates that the binding state between the optimal catalyst and the key reaction intermediates should be just right. It should not be too weak, otherwise the reaction cannot be effectively promoted; nor should it be too strong, as this would make it difficult for the intermediates to further transform, thus hindering the entire reaction process. Based on the above descriptions and the constructed theoretical framework, in-depth research can be carried out on many reaction intermediates involved in the CO2RR on metal surfaces through theoretical prediction. For example, Xiao et al. studied the efficient electrochemical reduction of CO2 on the surface of the two-dimensional metal-organic framework M3(2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene)2. First, the study compared the linear scaling relationship of thermodynamic stability with the volcano plot (Fig. 23 a, b). It was found that some M3(HITP)2 compounds showed effective selective performance for CO2RR according to the information presented in the volcano plot, enabling researchers to initially identify potential candidates from numerous compounds. Secondly, the volcano plot was constructed based on the limiting potentials of different intermediate species on the M3(HITP)2 surface. These limiting-potential scalings had similar correlations and strong thermodynamic activities. For example, in different systems with high kinetic activity (OH → H2O), the limiting-potential (UL) relationship of ΔG (OH) was approximately 0.75 eV, and the limiting potential of O → OH on the M3(HITP)2 catalyst was approximately 0.64 eV. Through the morphology of the volcano plot reflected by these data, researchers could judge the correlation between different intermediates and catalyst activity, and then screen out the M3(HITP)2 catalysts near the top of the volcano plot, where the intermediates were in the optimal binding-energy state. These catalysts could exhibit high catalytic activity for the electrochemical reduction of CO2 to hydrocarbon fuels at low over-potentials, helping researchers accurately screen out more efficient catalysts for CO2RR [161]. Jia et al. designed a new bimetallic borophene structure using particle-swarm optimization and utilized the volcano plot to assist in catalyst screening. Through high-throughput screening, seven CuMB4 (M = V, Zn, Nb, Ag, Cd, Ta, and Au) monolayers were identified as promising CO2RR catalysts. When the study deeply analyzed the complex relationships between the adsorption energies of various intermediates and the elementary steps in the C1 and C2 pathways, ΔE CO was taken as the key descriptor of the CO2RR limiting potential, and it was found to be closely related to the volcano plot (Fig. 23c, d). For C1 products, when the ΔE CO value of CuMB4 was close to −1.05 eV, an excellent limiting-potential (UL) value (∼0 V) appeared, as demonstrated by the CuZnB4 and CuCdB4 catalysts approaching the zenith of the volcano plot. For C2 products, when the ΔE CO of CuMB4 hovered around ∼−0.65 eV, the optimal UL value (∼−0.21 V) was achievable, with CuZnB4 being a typical example. The volcano plot clearly showed the performance changes of catalysts under different ΔE CO values. Based on this, researchers could quickly locate the catalysts that could make the ΔE *CO value fall within the optimal range, that is, the CuMB4 materials near the top of the volcano plot, which had excellent catalytic activity. Thus, efficient CO2RR catalysts could be accurately screened out from numerous candidate materials, providing strong support for subsequent research and applications [162]. Vijay et al. dedicated themselves to exploring the activities of transition metals (TMs), metal-nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts (MNCs), and supported phthalocyanines in the CO2RR to CO reaction. By combining theoretical calculations with experimental measurements, they revealed the rate-limiting steps and related mechanisms of the reaction. The volcano plot (Fig. 23e, f) not only visually presented the activity trends of different catalysts, correlated the catalyst activity through the binding energies of key intermediates (CO2 and COOH), and provided a visual basis for evaluating and comparing catalyst performance, but also could determine the rate-limiting steps of the reaction at different potentials by calculating the free energy of intermediates, providing theoretical support for understanding the reaction mechanism. In addition, the activity trends revealed by the volcano plot provided a clear direction for designing ideal catalysts, which was of great guiding significance for the development of new and efficient CO2RR catalysts [163]. Jaramillo et al. carried out research work on typical polycrystalline tin electrocatalysts. They focused on exploring the scaling relationship between the partial current density and the binding energy calculated based on DFT, aiming to identify the favorable intermediates in the process of carbon dioxide conversion to formate (HCOO−). In this study, the two key factors, *COOH and *OCHO, were clearly identified in the kinetic-limitation region. Moreover, researchers found that for various metal electrocatalysts, the local current-density descriptors corresponding to their current-density descriptors followed the pattern of the volcano plot. Through this series of research and analysis, it was finally determined that at the peak position of the volcano plot, the optimal metals for the formation of CO and formate (HCOO−) were Au and Sn, respectively. This result exactly conformed to the laws expounded by the Sabatier principle, further verifying the effectiveness and importance of the volcano plot in catalyst research and screening. In the field of doped electrocatalysts for carbon dioxide reduction, the volcano plot is set to undergo multi-dimensional in-depth development. Theoretically, with the continuous improvement of the accuracy of quantum chemical calculations, the calculation of adsorption energy and activity parameters in constructing the volcano plot will become more precise. This allows for a more detailed reflection of the relationship between the microscopic structure and performance of the catalyst. It helps to precisely locate the ideal positions of different doping systems on the plot, thereby guiding the development of catalysts with better intrinsic activity. Experimentally, the advancement of high-resolution and in-situ characterization techniques can provide the volcano plot with more abundant and realistic experimental data, effectively narrowing the gap between theory and practice. For example, in-situ spectroscopy can capture in real-time the changes in surface species of the catalyst during the reaction, providing direct evidence for determining parameters such as adsorption energy. Meanwhile, to overcome the limitation that a single volcano plot can only reflect a limited number of factors, the construction of multi-variable volcano plots will become a trend. By comprehensively considering more actual reaction conditions such as temperature, pressure, and electrolyte composition, these plots can fully present the catalytic laws in complex systems. In addition, the combination of the volcano plot with other methods shows great potential. When combined with machine learning, the powerful data-mining ability of machine learning can deeply analyze a large amount of volcano-plot data, discover potential relationships between catalyst structure and performance, and accelerate the screening process. When used in conjunction with high-throughput experimental techniques, it can quickly obtain the performance data of a large number of different doped catalysts, efficiently populate the volcano plot, and achieve rapid iterative optimization. This collaborative model of multiple methods will greatly promote the research and development of doped electrocatalysts for carbon dioxide reduction, and contribute to the goal of efficient carbon dioxide conversion and utilization. 6.2 Free-energy diagram In the investigation of electrochemical CO2 reduction, a comprehensive reaction pathway is governed not by singular descriptors focusing solely on reactivity or selectivity, but rather by the synergistic interplay of optimized thermodynamic and kinetic parameters. Specifically, the adsorption/desorption energy barriers of multiple key intermediates collectively regulate the reaction progression. The free-energy diagram serves as a robust analytical framework to screen optimal reaction channels from competitive adsorption configurations, while explicitly elucidating the activation energies of rate-determining steps and inhibitory barriers governing selectivity through potential energy surface evolution. Xie et al. obtained these free-energy diagrams through DFT calculations in their study. Fig. 24 a shows the relationship diagram of two-dimensional C2+ activity (ΔG OCCOH) and C1 and C2+ selectivity (ΔG OCCOH-ΔG OCHOH) for CO2RR to C1 and C2+ products on bimetallic X-Cu(111). By comparing the positions of different bimetallic catalysts formed by various metals and Cu in this diagram, catalysts with high C2+ product formation activity and selectivity can be clearly screened out. Among them, Pd-Cu is found to be the most promising candidate, with the lowest values of ΔG OCCOH and ΔG OCCOH-ΔG OCHOH, providing important thermodynamic trend evidence for screening efficient catalysts. Fig. 24b presents the free-energy diagrams for CO2RR to produce C1 products (represented by CH4) via the CHO pathway and C2 products (represented by C2H4) via the OCCOH pathway. This diagram intuitively shows the free-energy changes of intermediate products during the reaction on Pd-Cu and Cu catalysts, further demonstrating the advantages of the Pd-Cu catalyst in promoting C–C coupling and suppressing the HER [123]. In the study conducted by Tan et al., these free-energy diagrams were obtained by constructing different catalyst systems and performing DFT calculations. Fig. 24c shows the free-energy changes from CO2 to CO on Cu(111), AgCu, SnCu, and Ag/SnCu. It clearly indicates that the Gibbs free energy (0.72 eV) for the formation of *COOH on Ag/SnCu is lower than that on Cu(111), AgCu, and SnCu. This shows that the combined action of Ag and Sn atoms reduces the formation energy of *COOH species, thus promoting the CO2RR process and providing an energy basis for screening catalysts with better CO2 activation ability. Fig. 24d presents the charge-density differences of the most stable *COOH adsorption configurations on Cu(111), AgCu, SnCu, and Ag/SnCu. It shows that the Cu sites on the Ag/SnCu surface can provide more electrons to the *COOH species than other catalysts. This strong electron interaction helps to activate the CO2 molecule and stabilize the *COOH intermediate, further indicating the advantages of this catalyst in the reaction and being of great significance in screening efficient catalysts. Fig. 24e shows the free-energy diagrams for H2 on Cu(111), AgCu, SnCu, and Ag/SnCu, indicating that the incorporation of Ag and Sn atoms inhibits the HER kinetics during the CO2RR process. This is crucial for screening catalysts with high selectivity because suppressing HER can improve the selectivity of CO [113]. Through DFT simulations that model distinct catalytic site architectures, which include transition metal-doped NiMN6 (M = Zn, Co, Cu, Mn, Cr, V, and Ti) and pristine NiN4 centers, Zhu et al. derived critical mechanistic insights, as detailed in Fig. 24f–g. The Gibbs free-energy profiles show the stepwise energy variations during the conversion of CO2 to CO in these catalytic systems. Comparative analysis revealed uniformly lower ΔG values for *COOH intermediate formation at all NiMN6 sites versus NiN4, demonstrating heterometallic doping enhances the kinetics of the initial electron transfer at Ni active centers. This energetic advantage provides quantitative criteria for screening optimized catalytic configurations. Fig. 24g further contrasts thermodynamic overpotentials for CO2 reduction and hydrogen evolution, with their differential quantifying site-specific activity/selectivity trade-offs. The NiMN6 systems exhibited higher than NiN4, confirming enhanced CO2RR preference through strategic metal pairing [93]. These computational metrics establish dual design principles: modulating intermediate stabilization energies to control reaction kinetics, and engineering overpotential gaps to steer selectivity. Through comprehensive analysis of these data, catalyst sites with better performance such as NiCuN6 can be clearly screened out, which are outstanding in reducing the reaction energy barrier and improving catalytic selectivity, fully demonstrating the key role of free-energy diagrams in the catalyst screening process. In the study conducted by Du et al., the free-energy diagram in Fig. 24h was obtained through DFT calculations. Fig. 24h shows that on the Ag-doped Cu(100) surface, the transition-state (TS) values for C-C coupling via the *CO-*CHO and *CO-*COH reactions are 0.45 and 1.10 eV, respectively. By comparing with the transition-state energy (0.55 eV) of the *CO-*CHO reaction on the pure Cu(100) surface, the influence of Ag doping on the energy barrier of the C–C coupling reaction is clearly shown, which can help screen out catalyst structures more favorable for the C–C coupling reaction and is of key significance for analyzing the mechanism of the catalyst in promoting the formation of multi-carbon products. The continuous innovation of calculation methods will enable more accurate simulations of the actual reaction environment. Factors such as solvation effects and the complex interactions at the electrode-electrolyte interface will be effectively taken into account. As a result, free-energy diagrams that highly match the real reactions can be drawn, greatly enhancing the reliability of reaction mechanism analysis and catalyst performance prediction. To address the problem of difficult identification of numerous reaction intermediates in complex reaction systems, new theoretical analysis tools and algorithms will emerge continuously. These will help comprehensively and accurately identify and characterize intermediates, thus improving the construction of free-energy diagrams [164]. Advances in experimental techniques also provide strong support for free-energy diagrams. Highly sensitive in-situ spectroscopy techniques can track in real-time the dynamic changes in the concentrations of various substances and the evolution of chemical bonds during the reaction, providing intuitive and reliable data for determining the energy states at each point on the free-energy diagram. Moreover, when free-energy diagrams are combined with machine learning, machine-learning algorithms can quickly analyze large amounts of free-energy diagram data, discover hidden patterns and trends, and assist in designing more efficient doping strategies. When used in conjunction with molecular dynamics simulations, it can dynamically show the reaction process at the atomic scale, providing a microscopic interpretation of the physical nature of the energy changes in the free-energy diagram. 6.3 Data-driven machine learning Active machine learning methods have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in numerous reactions. The significant improvement in efficiency makes it possible to apply these methods to the electrochemical CO2RR. However, the application of this approach requires meeting several pre-conditions, including the properties of CO2, the active sites of electrocatalysts, and the interactions between them. The thermodynamic properties of CO2 in solutions can be explored through machine learning frameworks. Machine learning-enhanced computational frameworks enable high-throughput screening of over 300,000 catalytic candidates for CO2 capture optimization. Advanced multiscale modeling strategies integrating quantum mechanical precision with neural network acceleration systematically probe 5,000–10,000 distinct surface configurations per catalyst, identifying energetically favorable active sites for selective CO2 electroreduction. This dual-scale approach combines ab initio quantum calculations with intelligence driven pattern recognition to resolve atomic-level adsorption energetics while maintaining computational tractability across macroscopic catalyst libraries. Gao et al. constructed a knowledge graph of Cu-based electrocatalysts based on the SciBERT framework. By extracting various entity information such as materials, regulation methods, products, and FE, and integrating semantic information and the correlation of knowledge triples with the help of a deep-learning model, they effectively achieved the prediction of FE in the CO2RR. This provides new ideas and methods for catalyst design in this field and demonstrates the application potential of machine learning in this research direction (Fig. 25 a) [165]. Mok et al. proposed an innovative machine-learning-assisted high-throughput virtual screening (HTVS) strategy. They studied 465 metal catalysts by combining a DSTAR-based binding-energy prediction model with a 3D CO2RR selectivity diagram. Among them, the 3D selectivity diagram shown in Fig. 25b is particularly crucial. It constructs a potential-dependent selectivity map using three binding-energy descriptors, intuitively presenting the selectivity tendencies of different metals towards products such as formate, CO, C1, and H2. This provides important evidence for understanding the selectivity of catalysts and strongly promotes the discovery process of electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction [166]. Li et al. focused on the C–C coupling reaction in the electrochemical CO2RR in this paper. To explore its mechanism and screen catalysts, they constructed a large-data set of 45,738 data points, covering six precursor combinations and adsorption configurations, and applied iterative sampling, 2D-3D integrated machine-learning technology, and DFT calculations. In model development, they adopted a 2D-3D integration strategy combining the DimeNet++ and GCN algorithms, reducing the mean absolute error (MAE) of adsorption-energy prediction to approximately 0.32 eV. As shown in Fig. 25c–h, there is a strong linear relationship (most R 2 coefficients > 0.8) between the adsorption energies of C1 coupling precursors and between precursors and C2 coupling products at the ABCu site, which is stronger than that on pure-metal surfaces, providing a basis for evaluating the reaction. Through analysis, it was determined that asymmetric coupling is more favorable. For example, CHO-CH and CHO-CH2 are relatively optimal pathways, and 11 catalysts were screened out. Among them, the FE of C2 products of CuAgNb in the C–C coupling reaction was experimentally verified to be higher than that of Cu and CuAg, providing an example for relevant research. Sargent and colleagues developed a computational framework integrating volcano plot scaling relationships with machine learning-derived CO adsorption energies to screen catalytic sites, identifying approximately 4,000 candidate configurations for ethylene production. Dimensionality-reduced t-SNE visualization of activity-selectivity volcano maps pinpointed Cu-Al bimetallic clusters as promising candidates. Structural characterization revealed that Cu-Al bridge sites, where copper atoms predominantly coordinate the aluminum centers, exhibit enhanced CO2-to-ethylene conversion efficiency due to optimized *CO dimerization energetics [167]. While computational models have significantly advanced ECO2RR catalyst design, their predictive accuracy remains constrained under realistic reaction conditions. Practical electrocatalytic interfaces involve dynamic active site reconstruction, multiphase interactions, pH gradients, and competitive adsorption among identified intermediates which factors rarely incorporated in current simulations. Bridging this gap requires synergistic integration of operando characterization, microkinetic modeling with explicit solvation layers, and high-resolution in situ spectroscopic mapping of intermediate populations. Molecules and ions diffuse and react near the electrode. At the atomic level, the interface is complex and unstable, and the system is dynamic and non-equilibrium. The original static surface models cannot fully describe the charged interface, necessitating more accurate theoretical models. Recent advancements in surface detection techniques, such as operando spectroscopy and microscopy, have provided valuable insights into charged interfaces. At the same time, sophisticated atomic description methods, including machine learning, have deepened our understanding of electrified interfaces. Large-scale Monte Carlo simulations, molecular dynamics, and neural network atomic potentials have enabled the exploration of complex systems on a grand scale. Machine learning has become a promising new approach for identifying ideal catalysts. The combination of large-scale simulations and extensive experimental data has made high-throughput science more achievable [168]. Deep learning, a subset of machine learning, offers unique advantages, such as automated feature selection. However, it typically requires long training periods and reinforcement learning. Integrating multi-physics simulations into mass transfer and field effects can further enhance the functionality of the ECO2RR system. 7 Conclusion and outlook CO2RR, a pivotal pathway toward carbon neutrality, has achieved remarkable progress through the development of copper-based hybrid catalysts. These advanced materials enhance product selectivity and catalytic durability via precise modulation of electronic configurations at active sites, surface adsorption characteristics, and localized reaction microenvironments. Systematic investigations reveal three key doping strategies: main-group metal incorporation optimizes electron density distribution to create novel active sites for enhanced CO2 adsorption/activation; transition metal integration leverages variable oxidation states to facilitate charge transfer while suppressing competing hydrogen evolution; nonmetal substitution restructures chemical bonding networks to improve catalytic performance. Collectively, these strategies elucidate synergistic mechanisms between dopant properties (ionic radius, valence states, coordination preference) and substrate microarchitecture (surface roughness, porosity), establishing a theoretical framework for “catalyst genome” design. In mechanistic exploration, operando techniques including time-resolved XRD and DEMS enable dynamic monitoring of structural evolution and intermediate transformation. While constrained by crystalline ordering requirements and limited volatile species detection, these approaches provide critical insights into reaction pathways. The integration of computational modeling with high-throughput screening has overcome traditional trial-and-error limitations through predictive tools such as volcano plots, free energy diagrams, and machine-learning descriptors. Notably, differential regulation of key intermediates (*COOH/*CO) adsorption by transition metals versus nonmetals, coupled with multimodal characterization (e.g., operando XAS-Raman spectroscopy), represents groundbreaking advancements in the field. Future directions should emphasize the convergence of atomic-precision synthesis, dynamic mechanism elucidation, and scalable manufacturing protocols to bridge the gap between fundamental research and practical implementation of efficient CO2 electrocatalytic conversion systems. Nevertheless, significant challenges persist in this field. For doping technologies, achieving precise, uniform, and stable incorporation remains a critical bottleneck. Current synthetic approaches lack sufficient control over dopant positioning, concentration gradients, and spatial distribution, frequently resulting in performance inconsistencies and structural instability that compromise practical reliability. Furthermore, the intricate electronic structure modifications and surface reconstruction phenomena induced by doping lack comprehensive theoretical interpretation, particularly regarding electron transfer dynamics and orbital hybridization patterns, which hinder rational design principles for dopant selection. From a systemic perspective, CO2RR performance is intricately governed by multiple interdependent parameters including electrolyte composition (pH, cation/anion species), applied potential windows, temperature/pressure conditions, and mass transfer limitations. This complexity poses substantial challenges in optimizing doped Cu-based catalysts while simultaneously mitigating parasitic reactions like carbonate formation and catalyst corrosion under realistic operating conditions. Moreover, most reported systems remain confined to laboratory-scale demonstrations, with insufficient exploration of scalable fabrication protocols, industrial-grade current density operation (>500 mA cm−2), and standardized long-term stability assessments (≥ 1,000 h)-essential benchmarks for commercial viability. To address these limitations, three strategic directions emerge: (1) Advancing atomic-level precision synthesis through emerging techniques like colloidal atomic layer deposition and single-atom confinement strategies; (2) Decoupling dynamic interface evolution from bulk phase transformations using multimodal operando characterization coupled with multiscale simulation techniques; (3) Establishing machine learning-guided automated platforms integrating high-throughput experimentation, real-world operating condition simulations, and failure mode analysis. Concurrently, developing standardized testing protocols and accelerated aging models will be crucial to bridge the gap between fundamental studies and industrial implementation. Future breakthroughs will likely emerge from synergistic innovations crossing materials informatics, advanced manufacturing, and mechanistic understanding of structure-performance correlations under practical operational stresses. 1. Integrating multi-physics simulations into mass transfer and field effects can enhance the functionality of the ECO2RR system. To achieve profound mechanistic insights into dynamic interfaces and mass transport, it is critical to overcome the limitations of conventional “static surface” models. During practical electrocatalytic operation, the electrode-electrolyte interface undergoes continuous dynamic reconstruction, exemplified by Cu facet oxidation/reduction oscillations and dopant segregation phenomena, while existing characterization techniques fail to capture these transient processes. Advanced spatiotemporally coupled operando characterization systems must be developed: subsecond-resolution synchrotron-based rapid X-ray imaging (<100 ms temporal resolution) could enable real-time tracking of active site evolution under high current densities (>500 mA cm−2), while surface-sensitive sum-frequency generation (SFG) spectroscopy integrated with electrochemical impedance analysis may elucidate dynamic regulation of intermediate adsorption energies by localized pH gradients. Concurrent integration of quantum mechanical calculations and molecular dynamics simulations is essential to establish multiscale dynamic reaction network models, clarifying the coupling mechanisms between evolving coordination environments and electrolyte interfacial effects. Future advancements should prioritize operando characterization technologies with enhanced spatiotemporal resolution (atomic-scale structural monitoring with millisecond response times) and multidimensional correlative methodologies that bridge atomic-level structural dynamics with macroscopic performance metrics. These developments will provide critical insights into the dynamic evolution processes spanning atomic configurations to reaction pathways, offering a robust foundation for rational catalyst design and mechanistic exploration. 2. Rational design and high-throughput development of novel doping systems The rational development of advanced doped catalysts necessitates the integration of cutting-edge synthesis techniques with data-driven strategies. Moving beyond conventional metal doping approaches, emerging methods such as atomic layer deposition and ion implantation enable the construction of nonmetal (e.g., P, B) and multi-element synergistic doping architectures. Concurrently, non-equilibrium doping technologies including femtosecond laser-induced transient doping and electric field - assisted dynamic doping offer novel pathways. The former exploits ultrafast laser melting-quenching processes to create metastable high-entropy alloy surfaces on Cu substrates, enhancing *CO-CO intermediate coupling efficiency, while the latter utilizes bias-controlled elemental migration to establish potential-dependent adaptive active sites. Machine learning-powered “element-electronic structure-performance” predictive models, coupled with high-throughput screening platforms combining scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) and X-ray fluorescence imaging, could accelerate catalyst evaluation (>1,000 samples/day). Parallel development of graph neural networks (GNNs) to simulate dynamic surface/interface evolution in electrolyte environments would establish computational-experimental closed-loop validation systems, particularly addressing stability challenges in single-atom catalysts. These methodologies transform traditional empirical approaches into theory-guided design paradigms, significantly expediting the discovery of high-performance catalytic materials. 3. Fitness optimization of industrial-scale electrolysis systems To facilitate the industrial application of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction technology, it is essential to bridge the performance gap between laboratory-grade H-type electrolytic cells and industrial membrane electrode assembly (MEA) systems. Current research must concentrate on three core issues: CO2 mass transfer limitation at high current density (>500 mA cm−2), long-lasting catalyst stability (>1000 h) in strong acidic/alkaline environments, and synergistic optimization of product separation and system EE. The mass transfer bottleneck at high current densities can be mitigated by designing gradient porous copper-based gas diffusion electrodes. For example, micrometer-scale copper dendrites are employed as an outer layer along with a nanoporous doped copper inner layer. Moreover, developing functionalized anion-exchange membranes, such as those having surface-grafted-NH3+ groups, can help inhibit the solubility loss of doped metals (like Ag/Au) through electrostatic interactions. As a result, both catalyst stability and product selectivity are enhanced. At the same time, it is necessary to build an integrated electrocatalytic-separation system, such as coupling CO2RR and anodic oxidation reaction design, through the optimization of the reaction path to achieve the system energy efficiency. In the future, we should accelerate the development of scale-up preparation process, combined with in-situ stability test and full life cycle cost analysis, to promote the leap of copper-doped catalysts from basic research to industrial application, and to provide key support for the commercialization of carbon recycling technology. 4. Full life cycle assessment and carbon neutral closed-loop construction In order to realize the sustainable development of copper-based carbon dioxide electrocatalytic reduction technology, it is necessary to build a full life cycle assessment and carbon neutral system integration system. The environmental impact evaluation standard for doping materials should be established by quantifying the balance between catalyst preparation energy consumption, precious metal usage and carbon emission reduction benefits. Moreover, transition metals from metallurgical waste should be prioritized as doping sources to reduce environmental costs. At the same time, it is necessary to develop electrocatalytic-biocatalytic cascade technology, such as coupling the C2+ olefins generated by the reaction with engineered bacterial strains to synthesize biodegradable polymers in a targeted manner, so as to realize high-value utilization of the products. The whole chain of carbon capture, electrocatalytic conversion and product application should be further integrated to form a “carbon negative” closed-loop system: carbon dioxide from industrial waste gas should be utilized as a raw material, and efficiently converted into chemicals such as ethylene and ethanol through copper-doped catalysts, and then used in the production of degradable plastics or fuel additives, so as to ultimately build a circular economic model from carbon sources to end products and promote the substantial realization of the goal of carbon neutrality. 5. Establishment of multidisciplinary cross-innovation platform The innovative development of copper-based carbon dioxide electrocatalytic reduction technology needs to build a multidisciplinary cross platform to promote the multi-field coupling of electrocatalysis with photoelectricity and thermocatalysis, such as the development of photoelectricity-thermal synergistic catalytic system, the use of solar energy to drive the reaction and optimize the mass-transfer efficiency, and at the same time the design of biomimetic catalysts-drawing on the mechanism of multi-metal synergism in enzyme catalysis, the Simulate the proton-electron dynamic transfer process through atomic-level synergy between rare earths and transition metals. Integrate materials genome engineering and artificial intelligence to build a “data-computation-experiment” intelligent R&D system: establish a multi-dimensional database covering doping parameters and performance indexes, and combine the graph neural network prediction model with a high-throughput automated experimental platform to realize the targeted design of catalysts. Modular electrolysis systems will be developed in conjunction with microfluidics and chemical equipment. Membrane electrode assemblies with adaptive mass-transfer channels will be prepared using 3D printing. Environmental costs will be reduced through the metallurgical waste recycling and catalyst regeneration recycling system. Ultimately, a full-chain innovation ecosystem that extends from atomic-scale mechanism research to industrial-scale system integration will be formed. Uncited references [68,69,70,160]. Meifang Huang is currently a Ph.D. student supervised by Assoc. Prof. Jinlong Zheng at the School of Mathematics and Physics, University of Science and Technology Beijing. Her research activities focus on the synthesis and study of Cu-based catalysts and their related CO2RR properties. Chenjing Wang is a master's student at the University of Science and Technology Beijing, under the guidance of Associate Professor Jinlong Zheng. Her current research interests include the design and synthesis of functional nanomaterials, as well as the application of density functional theory (DFT) calculations and related electrocatalytic performance analysis. Yanru Yuan is currently a doctoral student supervised by Dr. Jinlong Zheng at the Beijing Advanced Innovation Center for Materials Genome Engineering, Institute for Advanced Materials and Technology, University of Science and Technology Beijing. Her research activities focus on the synthesis and study of transition metal catalysts. Binbin Jia obtained his Ph.D. in School of Chemistry at Beihang University in 2020 under the supervision of Prof. Lin Guo. He was then a postdoctoral researcher at Beihang University from 2020 to 2023. He is currently an associate professor in College of Materials and Chemical Engineering at Three Gorges University, China. His research interests focus on the synthesis of amorphous nanomaterials for the applications in electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Xiaoyu Fan, a Master's Supervisor at Capital Normal University, earned her Ph.D. from Beihang University in 2021 under Professor Lin Guo. She was an assistant research fellow in National Center for Nanoscience and Technology from 2021 to 2024. She joined the Department of Chemistry at Capital Normal University in July 2024. Her work focuses on synthesizing inorganic nanomaterials and their applications in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. Jinlong Zheng is an associate professor in Beijing Advanced Innovation Center for Materials Genome Engineering at University of science and technology Beijing, China. He received his Ph.D. from Beihang University in School of Chemistry in 2016. He undertook postdoctoral researches at Beihang University from 2017 to 2018. His research interests focus on the development of advanced electrocatalyst through surface and interface engineering, the application of theoretical calculation in electrocatalysis to enhance the understanding of structure-activity relationship, andthe machine learning for material design innovation.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction is a crucial method for addressing energy issues and achieving carbon neutrality. Doping of Cu catalysts represents an effective approach to regulate electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction. This review article summarizes the research progress on improving the performance of Cu-based material electrocatalysts through doping regulation. The background, fundamental research, evaluation parameters, and methods for catalyst design, along with their influencing factors, are introduced. Emphasis is placed on the impact of doping with different elements (such as noble metals, transition metals, main-group metals, non-metals, etc.) on the performance of Cu-based catalysts, including the mechanisms for enhancing activity, selectivity, and stability. In-situ characterization techniques have revealed the structural evolution and catalytic mechanisms during the doping process. Mechanistic studies, leveraging the ever-advancing computational capabilities and high-throughput methods, have given rise to typical computational descriptors like volcano plots, free-energy diagrams, and machine-learning-based approaches. These descriptors have become key tools for screening high-efficiency catalysts in various application scenarios of the electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR). This article comprehensively summarizes the current research achievements and looks ahead to the future, indicating that strengthening the combination of theory and experiment and exploring industrial applications are the future research directions, aiming to provide a comprehensive reference for the development of highly efficient doped Cu-based electrocatalysts.
